    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 3d • 3 days ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Are PM take-home assignments dead? Here's a thought.

    Anyone can now:

    - Run NotebookLM to summarize 10+ insight-rich sources.
    - Fire up Deep Research to investigate a market or your product.
    - Have an LLM summarize yours and your competitor's G2 reviews.
    - Push all that through an Agent Skill they have or find online.

    If you test whether they can build the traditional, boring document structure and surface-level insight just to see that they know the basics, you're not correlating with success at work.

    And let's not pretend it will just be "slop". It probably won't. More likely with a good prompt it will be *broadly* relevant and insightful.

    So here's a twist then.

    Your interview isn't a PM doing a take-home assignment.

    It is the PM reviewing a 100% AI-generated strategy or plan. Right there on the spot, they are to go through and provide commentary:

    - Show critical thinking when – especially when – the strategy looks plausible and well presented. We're all inclined to submit to a 'professional presentation' backed with data.
    - Show taste and character when insights are OK but not differentiating.
    - Turn a mountain of insights into a cohesive plan that leans onto unique strengths, not just average sensible best practice.

    For creative tactical thinking, you can always ask them to vibe prototype or sketch out a solution.

    What's the current thinking among hiring managers? hashtag#PM hashtag#Product hashtag#productmanagement hashtag#AI

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 4d • 4 days ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    The cost of rebuilding from scratch is going down, and that changes EvEryThiNg.

    The worst thing you could propose to a team is to revamp or rebuild a feature let alone the entire product. Even when that's the only way to crawl out of the tech debt, product debt, design debt pit they've dug for themselves over the years.

    They can keep crawling, which is often confused with surviving. It's just a prolonged dying, and some people feel safer like that.

    When you remove the technical obstacle, what stays is pure human resistance to change:

    - It works just fine as it is (revenue stalled)
    - We know how to sell it (we need to scale human labour to grow revenue)
    - Our team knows how to iterate on it (drowns in bugs and micro-optimizations)

    I don't see this mindset surviving through 2026/2027.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1w • 1 week ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Designers, don't build hashtag#Figma templates. Build hashtag#Agent Skills.

    There are more skilled designers than the training material for AI to generate products with some basic levels of taste.

    If you can package an Agent Skill that makes one of popular coding agents really know what they're doing, and produce designs that are a few steps ahead of the current state of the "art", people will pay for it.

    Why? The alternative is lots of frustration, spent tokens and hitting the token limit sooner. Opportunity cost is high, and people would rather ship core functionality than spend all their tokens on making the thing look and work nicely.

    Practical example: I'm toying with a personal fitness app – several agents that collect my data and make daily, weekly, 6-week adjustments. How hard could Material Design 3 Expressive with Kotlin and Jetpack Compose be?

    Wow. Very, very hard it seems. Gemini 3, Sonnet 4.5, Codex 5.2, I tried them all. (No Opus though!) With some *serious* context: my UX principles, component design, an Expressive Agent Skill I developed (that includes info from Material 3 website, even from Google's keynote transcript).

    And still it is mostly garbage. Functionally correct, design-wise total absolute garbage. I'm not nit-picking here. I mean garbage.

    If you can make some of these agents deliver "decent" quality design, I bet people will use it and pay for it. Good skills are anything that is relatively new, and there isn't a lot of training material online:

    - Material Design 3 Expressive (I'm guessing but the iOS equivalent here too)
    - Agentic patterns (tool calling, reasoning, approvals...)
    - Workflow designers (ReactFlow, visually designing agent loops, integrations...)

    There must be more. And each of these could easily be 3-5 skills, maybe more. With variations for different styles.

    In fact, you could make a showcase/marketplace for design skills (before/after) and infuse it with your consultancy CTAs. Getting off track here :)

    Will 2026 see better hashtag#agentic hashtag#UX and hashtag#UI hashtag#design? Is that good or bad? Not sure, but the gap is still wide, and you know it won't be filled by Senior Java Software Engineers!

    So much of SaaS is nonsense.

    Example: you want a retrospective tool for your team. If you search for one, chances are you'll find some of these tools that literally have a sidebar with 8-12 top-level menu items. What? Who builds these Frankensteins?

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1w • 1 week ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    There's lots of defensiveness around out there when it comes to speed of shipping. People take it personally. They argue that speed of coding was never the bottleneck (sure) and AI can't solve the speed of decision-making.

    Except that it can. Whatever an LLM is good at (it's good at more than just coding) can be orchestrated into an agentic framework to reason, make hypotheses, validate them, observe the findings, act, ask the human when needed, and loop until done. Strategy, problem definition and validation, prioritization are not some inherently impossible problems that is just too complex for AI, given the right inputs.

    The point being, the speed of shipping code is just one use for agentic AI. Speed of data analysis, of competitive analysis, of market research, problem definition, solution shaping, solution testing, prioritization... are all equally enabled by agentic AI. Not necessarily the same agentic AI that powers Claude Code or Codex, but still.

    Implying that the speed of delivery is basically pointless since the bottleneck has always been upstream, is not seeing forest for the trees. Upstream is getting faster too.

    Darko Stanimirović reposted this
    John CutlerJohn Cutler • FollowingVerified • Following Head of Product @Dotwork ex-{Company Name}Head of Product @Dotwork ex-{Company Name} 2w • 2 weeks ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    I'm amazed by how many companies talk about shifting from "project" to product funding, that can't assemble a basic business case for each team.

    Start here...

    For each team, write a business case explaining the financial rationale for why the team exists. What should this include?

    What are the enduring areas of focus, the “levers,” that this team has shown a track record of moving (or could spend more time moving if they were a better-defined team)? These levers should be stable and solution-agnostic, not fleeting or project- or work-focused.

    How has money in translated to money out? Remember second- and third-order effects, and time. Not every team will “create value” in the near term, but you should be able to frame a sensible guess or estimate here. Start from the thought experiment of the team not having done anything. What happened? What was the impact? The delta should get you in the vicinity.

    Put on your finance hat. What should the “pivot vs. proceed” tests be for this team in general? Is it even possible to “add money” to the team? What would happen? Could the team actually absorb more investment?

    How much of the team’s effort over the last year was squarely in line with the team’s mission and reason for being, versus adjacent, unacknowledged areas of helping?

    Now start answering some questions

    1. What problem gets materially worse if this team pauses for six months?

    2. What measurable outcomes would most clearly justify this team’s continued funding?

    3. Which costs would increase elsewhere in the organization if this team disappeared?

    4. What assumptions about demand, risk, or growth does this team carry?

    5. What work does this team do that no other team could realistically absorb?

    6. What signals would tell us this team’s model is no longer viable?

    7. What is the smallest version of this team that could still deliver its core value?

    8. Where does this team create optionality rather than immediate returns?

    9. If this team were funded as a contract instead of headcount, what would be in scope?

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 3w • 3 weeks ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Speed of shipping is going to be a hot topic in 2026.

    However, simply removing PMs from dysfunctional teams won't lead to the velocity promise. This is because those "PMs" are usually hired to manage a system that isn't built for velocity in the first place.

    They are hired to:

    - Understand the context of priorities given from above
    - Translate them to the teams who otherwise would lack the necessary insight
    - Micromanage the backlog as the team can't be trusted to prioritize on its own

    In high agency and high velocity environments, the system is built for speed from ground up. Teams form around outcomes more than outputs, (not exclusively and all the time, but directionally at least) engineers and designers are hired for their product skills as well, and PMs are looking at mid- to longer-term horizons more than the next 3 weeks.

    Those environments are rare.

    Remove a PM in a dysfunctional system and you'll be rehiring them shortly, directly or indirectly. But if you can reorganize the system that makes the 'product secretary' work necessary, I believe you can unlock velocity. It's just a lot more work and less likely to happen.

    This time around, there's no excuse. Your product needs the falling snow animation.

    How I'm grading websites in the next 4 weeks:

    Worst: No snow animation

    Okay: Static snow sprite, doesn't build up

    Good: Good depth, builds up at the bottom of the screen.

    Great: Builds up as you scroll and then you hit a $1.99 screen cleaning paywall

    AMAZING: Snow accumulates across sessions. You come back tomorrow and it’s still there. Support has a template that says it’s a “known issue.”

    UNHINGED: Invite emails include snow. Not a GIF. Real-time canvas snow rendered in the email client. Somehow.

    LEGENDARY: Snow density increases when third-party integrations are connected. Slack adds flurries. Salesforce adds hail. LinkedIn adds snowflakes shaped like clapping hands.

    TRANSCENDENT: Exports include snow. PDFs have embedded flakes. CSVs include a `snow_depth_mm` column.

    After Stanford, Berkeley hosts the second in a series of panels with students protesting in Serbia. This time, students from Novi Sad, Novi Pazar, Niš, and Belgrade will be in conversation with UC Berkeley students.

    Standing with Students in Serbia: the Promise of Organizing in and beyond the University
    December 10, 2025, 11 a.m. - 12:30 p.m.
    Online: Register here: https://lnkd.in/gjp5ZjjF
    In-person: Etcheverry 3109, UC Berkeley (2541 Hearst Ave; enter on Hearst, to the left of V&A Cafe)

    On November 1, 2024, the railway station canopy in Novi Sad collapsed, killing 16 people beneath it. In the days that followed, evidence pointed to widespread corruption as the cause of the disaster. What began as solemn vigils for the victims quickly transformed into the largest and most sustained protest movement in Serbia’s history.

    At the center of this movement are university students who have introduced a striking model of political organizing: horizontal, radically democratic, and yet highly disciplined. Despite the absence of centralized leadership, these students have successfully coordinated thousands of peaceful rallies, occupations, and marches across the country. Driven by a generation committed to accountability, justice, and lasting systemic change, this new movement is reshaping the entire society at the exact moment when meaningful change seemed impossible — in Serbia and around the world.

    The panel will feature student activists on the frontlines of this struggle in Novi Sad, Novi Pazar, Niš, and Belgrade. The discussion will be moderated by Berkeley students inspired by their counterparts in Serbia: Landry Krebs, Milena Novaković, and Allie Petrovski.
    Standing with Students in Serbia: the Promise of Organizing in and beyond the University

    Sam JacobsSam Jacobs • FollowingPremium • Following CEO @ Pavilion | Co-Host of Topline Podcast | WSJ Best Selling Author of "Kind Folks Finish First"CEO @ Pavilion | Co-Host of Topline Podcast | WSJ Best Selling Author of "Kind Folks Finish First"

    I've been doing this for 26 years. Helped raise close to $300B in capital. Seen three booms and busts. Built a community of 10K+ representing T’s in ARR.

    Here’s what I’ve learned:

    This time is not different.

    There is a class of AI founders who have convinced themselves that this time is different.

    This is happening right after we watched the collapse of the 2021 SaaS cohort, a generation of companies now stuck with zombie valuations.
    They thought it was different then too.

    The oldest rules of business still apply.

    Spend less than you make.
    Generate a profit.
    Understand your P&L.
    Do not push your valuation too high unless you take secondary.

    Focus on customer value and retention.

    The AI bubble is still a bubble.

    As Cassie wrote, many AI companies will hit a retention apocalypse.

    Experimental ARR, which never should have existed, will disappear as quickly as it appeared.

    A lot of value will be destroyed.

    For the rest of us, the old adages remain true.

    Manage your burn.
    Manage your valuation.
    Focus on efficiency.
    Deliver exceptional value.
    Tell interesting stories.
    Connect with authenticity and a point of view.

    It may take awhile.

    But customer value is always a longer path than investor value.

    Investors come and go.

    Customers are forever.

    2mo • 2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Never spend more time debating the priority of a product improvement than it would take to actually go ahead and do it.

    Small improvements add-up and they're morale boosters for both customers and the team.

    In the early times at HubSpot we had something called "daily delights". Basically, every day, the product team would *ship* at least ONE small improvement to the product that was noticeable by customers (and hopefully delight a few of them).

    We're bringing a variation of that idea back whereby we find and fix those minor annoyances in the HubSpot product and drive some customer delight. I'm thrilled.

    Sometimes companies have a tendency to overthink things and undervalue the compounding value of seemingly inconsequential improvements.

    Sangeet Paul ChoudarySangeet Paul Choudary • FollowingFollowing Author - Reshuffle, Platform Revolution | Senior Fellow, UC Berkeley | Advisory Boards - ING Bank, Standard Bank, GPA | CXO Advisor | Thinkers50 Strategy Award Winner | 4x HBR Top10 | WEF YGLAuthor - Reshuffle, Platform Revolution | Senior Fellow, UC Berkeley | Advisory Boards - ING Bank, Standard Bank, GPA | CXO Advisor | Thinkers50 Strategy Award Winner | 4x HBR Top10 | WEF YGL 1mo • 1 month ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    There are two kinds of people who don't understand the power of LLMs.

    The first group insists they are nothing more than glorified autocomplete - fun parlor tricks that hallucinate comically, with no real impact on how knowledge work is already changing.

    The second group is convinced they are the opening act of some mythical AGI that will soon outthink, outplan, and outlive us.

    What’s fascinating is that these two tribes, always yelling past each other and grabbing at each other's throats, share the same blind spot.

    They’re both so fixated on what LLMs aren’t that they completely miss what they already are.

    Darko Stanimirović reposted this
    Srđan KečaSrđan Keča • 1stVerified • 1st Professor @ Stanford | Filmmaker | Media that respects mindsProfessor @ Stanford | Filmmaker | Media that respects minds 2mo • 2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    TOMORROW: What Can Students Do to Save Democracy? Serbia Shows a Way Forward

    Panel of students from universities in Novi Sad, Novi Pazar, and Belgrade, and a member of a citizens' council from New Belgrade

    ⏰ Tuesday Nov 4 at 11am PT
    📍 Stanford University (in person) and Zoom (webinar)

    As democracy faces threats around the globe, what can young people do? In the face of this question, many feel powerless, cynical, or apathetic. This was the case in Serbia, until a unique student movement sprang up and offered a powerful and hopeful answer.

    On November 1, 2024, the collapse of a railway station canopy in Novi Sad killed 16 people, igniting public outrage as evidence pointed to systemic corruption having caused the deaths. What began as vigils for the victims rapidly transformed into the largest and most sustained protest movement in Serbia's history. At its heart are university students who have adopted a remarkable model of political organizing: horizontally structured, leaderless, yet extraordinarily disciplined. Despite having no central command, they orchestrated hundreds of massive peaceful rallies across the country, including the largest rally the country had seen, drawing more than 300,000 people to Belgrade on March 15, 2025.

    A striking feature of the movement is its strategic clarity. Rather than fracturing over traditionally divisive political issues, students built a broad, heterogeneous coalition united around simple demands: the restoration of the rule of law and democratic institutions. This approach has earned them the support of the majority of the population, a feat that has eluded opposition parties amid Serbia's captured media landscape. Professors, high school pupils, teachers, lawyers, farmers, war veterans and countless ordinary citizens all stepped up to support this movement, in the process rebuilding the consensus in Serbian society.

    After months of protests failed to secure accountability from the government, the students decided to take their movement to the ballot box. Rather than nominating themselves, they are assembling an electoral list of experts and professionals for the parliamentary elections they are demanding. In doing so, they have transformed from a protest movement into a major political force unlike anything currently operating in global politics.

    Join us for a conversation with students and professors from Serbia's protest movement as they share insights from this frontline of democratic renewal.

    https://lnkd.in/g_VX75SH
    What Can Students Do to Save Democracy? Serbia Shows a Way Forward
    events.stanford.edu

  • Feed post number 25

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2mo • 2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    There are two lines of critique against AI coding that miss the bigger picture:

    1. Fast delivery will increase AI slop; Products get bloated.

    Fast delivery doesn't mean you have to add net new features. You can refactor existing features more easily. Remove intertwined features that you've been delaying for years. Improve performance of existing features. Make larger scale redesigns.

    These efforts never get prioritized either due to complexity or relatively low perceived value.

    AI allows you to take on these previously mega efforts, and reduce bloat, tech debt, design debt, feature debt.

    2. The problem now is knowing what to ship.

    What a lovely problem. I'm yet to meet a product team that doesn't have a backlog of really cool ideas. Those are now stretched over multiple quarters. Is compressing them down to a single quarter really a problem?

    To an extent, it's true that this can be a challenge – in some environments more than the others – because the feedback loop doesn't only depend on delivery speed. But it largely does. And when the feedback loop compresses down, knowing what to ship will be more, not less obvious.

    It's only the teams detached from customers that will look up confused "what now?".

    ---

    The tactical, near-term side of prioritization will actually be easier when the feedback loop is faster. All the insights will feed into hashtag#AI real-time and with the right tooling, Product Engineering teams will have what they need to make tactical decisions. RIP Product Owner. Hello, hashtag#Product Builders.

    Strategy will still be the beautiful creative challenge but with cycle times compressing it will be easier to de-risk our bets, and hopefully, more fun.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2mo • 2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Very accurate. Broken incentives will inevitably lead to a broken system.
    Valentina NochkaValentina Nochka • FollowingVerified • Following Product Leader | AI, E-commerce, HealthProduct Leader | AI, E-commerce, Health 3mo • 3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Let's stop confusing execution with delivery.

    I've been in that room. Someone says "we have an execution problem", and thirty seconds later they're proposing a new sprint ritual.

    Here's what's actually happening: we keep solving for delivery when the problem is execution.

    Delivery is about output. Tickets closed, features shipped, velocity charts trending up. It's visible, measurable, manageable.

    Execution is about system design: how your organization actually turns intent into outcomes. It's the invisible architecture that determines whether you're learning or just busy.

    Think of it as a feedback loop. Delivery is what comes out at the end. Execution is how fast and truthfully that loop closes, how quickly you notice what's broken and actually fix it.

    A team that only optimizes for delivery pushes features. A team that executes well notices when standups became status reports and changes the format. They see when estimates are inflated to pad safety margins and redesign the incentive. They catch signal degradation before it becomes a crisis.

    This confusion is expensive. Teams add process when they need system redesign. They hire delivery managers when the incentive structure is broken. They obsess over velocity while the real bottleneck is in how decisions get made.

    And here's the hardest part: execution is never a PM's solo duty. It's a shared system -- the way product, design, and engineering translate intent into trust. You can't own it alone. You can only architect the conditions where good decisions become inevitable. (Well, inevitable is ambitious. Let's start with "not accidental".)

    Strategy is abstract coherence. You can workshop it, refine it, make it beautiful. Execution is dynamic alignment under uncertainty. It's organizational metabolism. You don't plan it; you tune it.

    So if you're a PM wondering where to start: ask different questions:
    Not "are we delivering on time?" but "what decisions are we making slowly?"
    Not "who owns this?" but "what feedback are we ignoring?"
    Not "how do we ship faster?" but "where do handoffs feel like blame?"

    Because when execution works, delivery stops being a problem. It just happens.

  • Feed post number 29

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 3mo • Edited • 3 months ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    The primary value of designers and PMs using AI to prototype isn't about handing PRs off to engineers. They don't want to be handed off code.

    The value is to reduce one of the 3 product risks we are responsible for:

    - Value risk: Confirm with customers and stakeholders that what you're building will be valuable before anyone writes a line of code. Does it solve a problem? Does it unlock new use cases? Does it make users ask "when is this going live?"

    - Usability: Is how you're thinking about this intuitive to users? Can they find it, understand it, get the task done with little friction? Is it easier than the alternatives?

    - Viability: To build a business case it helps if you can *show* and not just tell how a product change moves the needle. How it aligns with GTM or unlock new revenue. By prototyping early you can add substance to purely theoretical arguments.

    The outcome is not that the engineering team is served with a full working PR to approve, but that they work with fewer assumptions overall and have more confidence they're not just shipping useless product.

    Whether the team can take your PR as a useful artifact or not is an interesting technical, cultural, process problem but mostly besides the point of prototyping.

    Saanya OjhaSaanya Ojha • FollowingInfluencer • Following Partner at Bain Capital VenturesPartner at Bain Capital Ventures 3mo • 3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Sam Altman has been on a podcast blitz this week. 3 appearances in 5 days, each one a post-Dev Day sermon about the future of intelligence. I went through them all (fine, I read the transcripts) partly out of curiosity, partly out of professional obligation. When the person architecting the next platform shift narrates his thought process in public, you pay attention.

    Takeaways:
    ▪️The Verticalization of Intelligence
    → “I was always against vertical integration, and now I think I was wrong about that.”
    OpenAI’s biggest pivot since its founding: the lab is now an empire - building chips, models, and end-user interfaces in one continuous loop. In the intelligence economy, whoever controls compute and energy controls cognition.

    ▪️ Strategy as Evolution
    →“Let tactics become a strategy.”
    OpenAI’s R&D is Darwinian. Ship chaos, observe order, scale the mutation. Memory wasn’t conceived as a moat - users made it one. Altman’s genius isn’t foresight; it’s feedback.

    ▪️AI Scientists
    →“For the first time with GPT-5, we’re seeing little examples where models are doing science, making discoveries.”
    Altman’s AGI test is novel scientific discovery. Within two years, he predicts AIs will generate publishable research - and soon after, it’ll feel routine. Civilization’s next compounding force: automated invention.

    ▪️ Customization Is the New UX
    →“It would be unusual to think you can make something that would talk to billions of people and everybody wants to talk to the same person.”
    ChatGPT’s uniformity was naïve. The future: AIs that adapt tone, personality, and worldview to each user - an identity layer that mirrors your cognitive and emotional style.

    ▪️Post-Interface Computing
    →“You talk to your device and it does exactly what you want - then gets out of your way.”
    Voice is the natural endpoint of human-AI interaction - ambient, context-aware, invisible. The rumored io device is his post-screen bet: a computer that listens, reasons, acts. He is betting on the disappearance of interfaces.

    ▪️ Distribution Moves Inside the Assistant
    →“There will be a new distribution mechanic developers figure out… we’ll learn together.”
    Future startups will live or die by whether ChatGPT mentions them. It’s not SEO anymore; it’s AIO - Assistant Optimization.

    ▪️ The Democratization of Creation
    →“In the first few days, ~30% of users were active creators...”
    Altman sees creativity as universal, just bottlenecked by friction. Sora removes it, turning everyone into a micro-studio. The economics will follow: per-generation pricing for heavy users, rev-share for cameos, maybe ads if it tilts social.
    Compute is the new canvas: 1M downloads in <5 days, faster than ChatGPT.
    Altman’s worldview in one loop:
    Build → Release → Observe → Scale → Moralize Later.
    He’s a capitalist empiricist, not a philosopher.
    He summarizes: “AGI will come; it will go whooshing by… the world will not change as much as you’d think in a big-bang sense.”

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 3mo • 3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Two big tells for AI-generated content. And it's not the em dash. (BONUS: Why tells no longer matter)

    1. "Clarity"

    This is very subtle, but LLMs like to throw clarity in. Paste any document and ask what it really does, what impact does it really try to achieve, and you'll see it's about clarity. Look it up on Google Trends too. It trends up starting January 2025.

    2. Verboseness

    This one is a lot more obvious, but actually harder to alleviate.

    If you don't manage the length of your AI-assisted content, it erodes trust quickly. It makes people think:

    - You haven't read the content yourself, so why should they?
    - You haven't really thought about it enough to distill it into strong arguments.
    - You are blindly following what LLMs told you, especially if you are also strongly opinionated.

    ---

    Which brings me to my second point.

    It doesn't matter whether you used an LLM or not. An LLM "tell" is not really a thing anymore. Everyone uses AI.

    So the tell is really more about your skills and effort in using AI, not in whether you used it or not.

    That's why the em dash tell is mostly irrelevant, and verboseness is the next frontier.

    1. Harder to get right.
    2. More impactful for how your AI content – and your skills with it – is perceived.

    But guess what, I have a GUIDE for that. 👇

    (I don't actually. But there COULD be a GUIDE for it. Would you want it? COMMENT GUIDE below and let's see where this weekend takes me.)

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 3mo • 3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Confirmed by OpenAI.

    OpenAI released a workflow builder, and there are two distinct, but equally annoying voices in the community:

    1. OpenAI just killed 1000 startups.

    Sure. Just like the GPT Store killed 1000 startups in January last year. And GPT-5 was "GAME OVER". Keep your feeds healthy everyone. Prune those AI influencers from time to time.

    2. This is just AI Workflows, not agents!

    Funny how the same people mocking workflows worship models that only perform well because they were post-trained on structured workflows.

    Without some determinism, your multi-agent system is just an expensive compounding error generator.

    Even the flashiest "autonomous" agents rely on explicit orchestration – conditional logic, output validation, retry loops, integrations – the same primitives that workflows formalize. Just look at popularity of agent orchestration SDKs for proof.

    After all, if workflows are bad, why not just give one LLM 500 tools and call it AGI? Oh right. They're not at that point yet, you need to post-train them on instruction following, i.e. on workflows.

    hashtag#rant hashtag#ai hashtag#aiworkflows hashtag#openai hashtag#devday hashtag#aiagents
    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 4mo • 4 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    "If it's a workflow, it's not an AI agent!"

    OK sure, Wikipedia.

    But here's a hot take:

    If your AI agent does not have some level of deterministic, hard-coded logic in a "workflow", I would not trust that agent.

    Maybe with true AGI, but in 2025? Nope.

    The math is simple: every unbounded agentic step compounds the error. It's the equivalent of deaf phones.

    The boring, pre-2025 era determinism has a chance to stop the error from compounding. Yes, it limits the agent to some degree, but decreases the error rate.

    Which one do you sell better?

    - Agent that errors 45% of times while promising to solve 6 jobs perfectly? Or
    - Agent that does 1 job only but with an error rate of 5-8%?

    Korisničko iskustvo korišćenja elektronskog dnevnika:

    - U školi dobiješ papirić sa odštampanom šifrom. "Ovo nikako ne smete da izgubite". Na papiriću je samo šifra.

    - Niko ti ne kaže gde da ideš i šta da radiš. Dobio si šifru.

    - OK, kucaš "elektronski dnevnik" na Guglu.

    - Prvi rezultat je neki moj.esdnevnik.rs. Deluje kao SaaS app. Ne znaš čiji. Drugo je "esDnevnik" sa eUprave. Tamo naravno ne želiš da klikneš.

    - esdnevnik.rs ima i login sa nalogom sa eid.gov.rs. Super! Ne treba mi šifra, samo se povežem. "Грешка(Got error response: invalid_grant. Description: PKCE validation failed)". Ah. Naravno.

    - OK moraću da se ulogujem korisničkim imenom i šifrom. Čekaj, šta je korisničko ime? Nemam to. "Zaboravljena lozinka" traži korisničko ime. Kucam "darko", sigurno je to. Kucam imejl supruge. Enter -> forma se pošalje, ništa se ne desi. Kucam svoj imejl. Neka greška iskoči. AHA korak sam bliže verovatno je moj imejl mada ne stiže mi ništa.

    - Čekaj ko je ovaj sajt uopšte šta je ovo. Odem nazad na Gugl. Kliknem na eUpravu. Tamo ga zovu "esDnevnik" usluga. Tamo ima neki "spisak usluga" za esDnevnik. Klikneš, piše "esDnevnik". Klikneš na to, vrati te nazad gde si bio. Ima i link "više informacija o projektu esDnevniku" koji iz frustracije kliknem. 404. Ma naravno bre. Jaši narod!

    - Daj da vidim još na Guglu. Vidi ima ovaj neki "moja.eskola.rs". Kliknem kad ono IDENTIČAN LOGIN KAO moj.esdnevnik.rs. Ma da li me zajebavate. Sve iste ilustracije i boje. I tu *nema* logina sa eid.gov.rs. Jel ovo neki phishing? Jel me neko troluje?

    Da rezimiram: dobiješ šifru i 0 informacija. Imaš dva identična sajta na koje treba da upisuješ lične podatke. Ništa od toga ne radi.

    U ovom trenutku želim da mi mesečno štampaju izveštaj na papiru. Nemam pristup tehnologiji. Imate obavezu da mi obezbedite informacije na pristupačan način. Kancelarija za IT i eUpravu.

    Darko Stanimirović reposted this
    Saanya OjhaSaanya Ojha • FollowingInfluencer • Following Partner at Bain Capital VenturesPartner at Bain Capital Ventures 3mo • 3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    The rumors were true. Yesterday, OpenAI launched Sora 2, a next gen video + audio model. It makes clips that look shockingly real, with physics that obey Newton instead of Looney Tunes, and audio synced tightly enough to pass a lip-reading test.

    But the wild part isn’t the model, it’s the wrapper. Sora 2 arrives dressed as a social app with a vertical feed, remix tools, and a “cameo” feature to drop users into scenes. OpenAI is auditioning for TikTok’s job.

    Sure, the tech is very impressive - but it’s the strategic chess behind the launch that captured my attention:

    (1) The Scarcity Play

    Sora access is gated by invite codes or prioritized channels (like ChatGPT Pro). The scarcity play is obvious: invite codes = FOMO = viral hype. Silicon Valley has been playing this tune since Gmail.

    But here, exclusivity doubles as a throttle on chaos. By slowly onboarding users, OpenAI gets a live A/B test on how people will break, abuse, and subvert the system. Every invite code is basically a fuse on a firework: light it slowly, not all at once, or you blow off your hand. It’s not just growth hacking, it’s trust hacking.

    (2) The Copyright Play

    OpenAI also made the quietly radical decision to treat copyrighted material as fair game by default - unless the rights holder explicitly says no.

    Translation: if you own a movie, a character, a song - congratulations, your IP may now appear in someone’s Sora video unless you tell OpenAI not to. And even then, you might not be able to just say “don’t use anything I’ve ever made.” You’ll need to file takedowns for each work, one by one, like bailing water from a sinking ship with a thimble. Forever.

    It’s a legal Hail Mary, a moral shrug, and a strategic masterstroke all rolled into one. The brilliance (or cynicism) is that “opt-out” scales. Opt-in never would. And while courts grind through years of lawsuits, OpenAI normalizes the precedent simply by shipping it. The real beneficiaries? Beverly Hills law firms billing $2,000 an hour.

    (3) The Identity Play

    OpenAI is explicitly baking consent into likeness use. To appear in Sora, you first upload a verified “cameo”: a one-time video + audio clip that captures your face and voice. Only then can others use your likeness - and only with your permission. You stay a co-owner, can revoke access, and get notified whenever you’re dropped into a scene.

    It’s a meaningful attempt to center consent in synthetic identity. But it also opens a stranger frontier: identity as asset class.
    - Today it’s your friend putting your face in a video for fun.
    - Tomorrow it’s a talent agency managing a portfolio of “digital cameos” for actors, influencers, and eventually you.
    OpenAI didn’t just address deepfake abuse. They opened a market for identity futures. Identity is no longer just protected. It’s packaged, priced, and platformized. You, too, can rent your face for $99/month. Please read the terms of service.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 3mo • 3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    "Design is important".

    ChatGPT: Changes how recording button works on mobile every 2 weeks.

    - You can either record or type a prompt. Why would you want both?
    - You can now both record and type. It's a lot more intuitive!
    - You can now start recording but then you can *only* type.
    - After recording you must submit it at the same time, it's faster!
    - After recording we will show you the text first so you can verify.
    - Wait, we'll let you choose: either see text or submit it right away.
    - 1/5 times the recording will fail, you'll see "oops" and it's gone.
    - You can now record any time, even if you have entered text already. Very handy!
    - New update: we're no longer showing the sound waves as you speak. It seemed annoying!
    - The sound waves are back! Now you now if the sound is working!
    - From now on you can either record or type, not both. Clarity, finally.

    This is why we need designers.
    Ideally one designer. Not 10 of them on the same feature at once.

    Documenting your AI-coded projects is critical. Here's my 1-3-5 framework:

    Day 1:
    Generate documentation. Make it easy to follow, well structured, start high level and make it progressively more detailed. Split among just enough files.

    Day 3:
    Update documentation at a few places because the underlying behavior has changed considerably.

    Day 5:
    Delete docs/ folder and go to step 1.

    That's it. That's what I call the 1-3-5 documentation framework.
    Repeat every week and your documentation will always be up-to-date.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 3mo • Edited • 3 months ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Coding with AI compresses time.

    - Time to value
    - Time to technical debt
    - Time to complete refactors
    - Time to product debt
    - Time to customer feedback
    - Time to features you'd never build otherwise
    - Time to pivot
    - Time to giving up.

    I don't think we're built for this kind of time compression. It's very taxing and exhilarating at the same time.

    We can only process so much in a given time period.

    Can you review 5 PRs every day for 2 weeks?
    Can your team process 5 new updates you added this week?
    Can your customers adopt 4 net new features every month?

    There's little use in being able to run 80 km/h in a world that runs 8 km/h.

    Coding with AI a great power for startups and bootstrappers, but I wonder if there's a less visible cap to how much a single product team can truly benefit from it before they start falling apart.

    Something would need to change in the system for this to work. I believe this will be the biggest change by far. Not the speed by which we churn code and features.

    Perhaps counter-intuitive but non-technical and low-technical people are at an advantage at vibe coding to senior engineers.

    - Will learn more by trying more because if they don't vibe-code it, they will not have it. An engineer can sit down and build it. The other person can't.

    - In this process of trying and failing but not giving up, they learn ins and outs of the tool better than an engineer who gives up because AI mistakenly deleted a file or didn't follow the instruction 100%.

    - Engineers are less incentivized to learn AI coding since it threatens their skills. While I don't think it truly does, the incentive is just not there – all the process, tooling, supporting skills, it's all built around humans writing code. Ditching most of it for AI can feel like a regression.

    - Engineers are already waist-deep in the endless stream of tickets to work on. While AI could help, the process typically won't give them time to experiment with AI. Again, there's a 'process that works' and that process is predictable no matter how inefficient. It's how their performance is measured. Etc.

    Hackathons are a good ice breaker, but without a strong process, culture change from the top, performance review alignment, engineers will only feel frustration from everyone telling them "just use AI". It's not just.

    This is a culture problem. A process problem.

    You can't brute force that with Claude Code and vague expectations of velocity.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 4mo • 4 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    💪 A typical vibe coding workflow 💪

    1. Generates application logic, completes the PRD easily.

    2. Generates dozens of unit and integration tests for each functionality.

    3. All 86 tests are green. ✅✅✅✅✅✅✅✅✅✅✅✅

    3. You look at the tests and realize it got the basic logic in step 1 very wrong. Now you have 10 test files and 24 application files to fix at once.

    4. It promises to fix it all. You're absolutely right.

    5. All tests are green again. ✅✅✅✅✅✅✅✅✅✅✅✅

    6. Loop between 3-4-5 a few more times.

    7. You realize you need to drop 99% of the tests. Write or curate 2-3 core tests that you forbid AI from changing.

    I've been reluctant to go Test-Driven Development with AI but I am more and more confident that PRD-driven is not the right approach. Perhaps a PRD that lists out integration tests, not tasks. Then only after writing the tests, you get AI to complete the PRD with tasks, but only to satisfy one integration test at a time.

    Kyle DuPontKyle DuPont • 1stVerified • 1st CEO at Ohalo, Create order of data chaosCEO at Ohalo, Create order of data chaos 4mo • 4 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    A viral Hacker News thread just exposed a major AI compliance gap. Most CISOs and CDOs have no idea this is happening in their organization.

    What they discovered affects every regulated company: AI systems that pull sensitive information without creating the audit trails regulators expect.

    Here's the problem in plain terms: when your AI assistant answers questions, it's pulling information from company documents, emails, contracts, and databases. But instead of logging "John accessed the M&A contract," your audit system shows "John used AI assistant."

    When regulators ask "who accessed confidential client data last quarter?" you can't give them a real answer.

    This isn't theoretical. The thread reveals that major enterprise AI platforms have been logging AI interactions without tracking the underlying data access. Companies think they're compliant because they see AI usage in their logs, but they're missing what data the AI actually touched.

    For regulated industries, this creates serious exposure:
    - HIPAA audits require knowing who accessed patient records
    - SOC2 compliance depends on complete access logging
    - Financial services regulators want data lineage for AI decisions

    The regulatory examiner won't accept "the AI accessed it, but we don't know which files."

    The companies getting ahead of this are asking different questions:
    - Can we prove exactly what data our AI systems accessed?
    - Do our audit logs capture AI-driven data retrieval?
    - Would our current logging satisfy a regulatory examination?

    The AI governance frameworks that work aren't retrofitting compliance after deployment. They're building auditability into the foundation from day one.

    Because when regulators come asking about AI data access, "we don't know" isn't a compliance strategy.

    How confident are you in your current AI audit trails?

  • Feed post number 52

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 4mo • 4 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    A general rule when vibe coding: overspend on the data model.

    If you generate a PRD with several milestones, you'll be tempted to move too fast.

    Milestone 1: whatever, set the basics.

    Milestone 2: Build a cool feature!

    Milestone 3: You're almost there!

    Milestone 4: Stability and maintenance <-- Making $45k/mo already, so whatever!

    Wrong 🤣

    The data model is crucial. Everything gets informed by it. Your 40+ files you rushed to get in place all depend on it. Any change will often be partial, leaving your code in a messy, failing in-between state that can be tricky for AI to debug.

    You cannot spend too much time figuring this out.

    Figure out:

    - Edge cases
    - Near term scenarios (don't go too far but don't stay at next week either)
    - How your features interact with or constrain each other

    Once you get the foundation right, everything else flows easily. Get it wrong and you'll be lost in an endless loop of weird bugs before the product is usable. Sounds boring, but data model is important.

    "Anyone can vibe code, therefore engineers will be gone in no time". This only makes sense in the world where companies accept the current ceiling of developer productivity.

    If productivity is, say, 4 major features/refactors/upgrades per year.

    And suddenly AI enables that to be 8 major upgrades per year.

    Or 12.

    Do you think companies will say "well, we don't need these engineers anymore, we've hit our 4 features easily with [AI coding agent]"?

    Of course not.

    They'll want 20 now.

    I'm using "number of features" figuratively. Your customers can only process 1-2 major features each year but that's a whole different can of worms.

    The point being, "engineers are doomed" assumes the ceiling stays the same. It doesn't. The ceiling is growing.

    What I am confident will start happening next year is that engineers who don't want to grow with the ceiling will be left behind. This isn't necessarily about LOC written or features shipped – both being mostly vanity – this is about the pace of delivery in the increasingly more competitive environment.

    If a startup can copy your 7 yo stack in 2-3 months, you'll need to move fast or die. Refactors, infra upgrades, bugs, all of it. AI only makes you irrelevant if you keep delivering like it is 2012.

    A recent example of this is of a PM who "used ChatGPT to land multiple offers from [Meta, Tesla, whatever]".

    The visible part is:
    - Research the company, role, team, group, using Deep Research. Uncover extreme amounts of details about their customers.
    - Turn it into a podcast to listen to on the go and soak in all the context.
    - Practice scenarios, business models, pricing with ChatGPT.
    - Apply not to active job posts (that's for the rest of us) but directly to people who might be hiring at these large companies.
    - Get feedback that you know the business better than employees working there for months/years.

    That is how you win!

    The invisible part is:
    - Live in the largest tech hub on the planet.
    - Have direct access to Directors and VPs through friends and connections.

    I'm not discrediting the approach, it is/will be pretty normal in the age of AI. It's those invisible conditions that typically don't make up a significant part of the story, yet are critical to success.
    John CutlerJohn Cutler • FollowingVerified • Following Head of Product @Dotwork ex-{Company Name}Head of Product @Dotwork ex-{Company Name} 4mo • 4 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    A common mistake is believing success comes from mimicking the visible behaviors of successful people, companies, and organizations, while ignoring the invisible conditions that made those behaviors work.

    There are whole industries built on this tendency.

    This extends to listening to successful people diagnose why they are successful, and then copying those things. The catch is that people are often unreliable narrators of their own success.

    We are frequently seduced by wisdom that pantomimes our own internal monologue and worldview. We want to believe. We’re already pre-wired for the visceral response that says, “Yes, that must be it.”

    But for whatever reason, humans seem wired to connect: “Well, I guess they did X and they believed Y, therefore to achieve Z I must also do X and believe Y.”

    Brent LocksBrent Locks • 2ndPremium • 2nd Co-Founder & President at Builder.ioCo-Founder & President at Builder.io 5mo • 5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Finally watched Andrew Ng's video on AI's impact on product teams, and it aligns what we're seeing at Builder.io

    I built product teams in a past life. Usually it's one designer, one PM, and 4-8 engineers depending on the pod.

    So you have a 1:6 ratio on the PM side. Bundle PM and design together, and it's roughly 1:3.

    With visual IDEs, like Fusion, that ratio is about to flip completely.

    Here's what's happening: Product and design team members depend on engineering, to spec, prototype, and ship.

    Essentially, if you have an idea, then you need a developer.

    AI eliminates that friction. Now PMs and designers can spec, prototype, and validate a feature -- in hours, not weeks -- using actual production components and APIs.

    When teams can self-serve, engineering requirements shift.

    That 8-person engineering team becomes 2 people handling the same scope, and the rest of the team focuses on other high impact efforts.

    Andrew proposed 1 PM to 0.5 engineers, but I think he's cutting designers short.

    With the right tools and workflows, I think if you have 1 PM, 1 designer, and 1-2 engineers for most projects, you're going to be incredibly dangerous.

    If you're building products, this shift is already happening. The question is whether you're ahead of it or behind it.

    Hao HoangHao Hoang • 2ndPremium • 2nd Daily AI Interview Questions | Senior AI Researcher & Engineer | ML, LLMs, NLP, DL, CV, ML Systems | 42k+ AI CommunityDaily AI Interview Questions | Senior AI Researcher & Engineer | ML, LLMs, NLP, DL, CV, ML Systems | 42k+ AI Community 5mo • 5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    For over 60 years, Dijkstra's algorithm has been the undisputed champion for finding the shortest path in graphs. A new paper from researchers at Tsinghua University, Stanford University, and the Max Planck Institute for Multidisciplinary Sciences proves that even champions can be beaten.

    They've achieved the first major breakthrough for the directed Single-Source Shortest Path (SSSP) problem on real-weighted graphs, breaking the long-standing "sorting barrier" that made Dijkstra's algorithm seem optimal.

    Their method ingeniously combines the logic of Dijkstra's and the Bellman-Ford algorithms. Through a clever recursive technique, it avoids the need to fully sort vertices by distance, which was the core bottleneck.

    The result is a faster, deterministic algorithm that runs in O(mlog2/3n) time.

    This is a huge deal for theoretical computer science and has practical implications for speeding up route calculations in GPS, optimizing data flow in computer networks, and improving efficiency in logistics. A fundamental problem just got a new, faster solution.

    Darko Stanimirović reposted this
    Tamir Ishay SharbatTamir Ishay Sharbat • 2nd2nd Security, AI and everything in betweenSecurity, AI and everything in between 5mo • 5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    We got ChatGPT to leak your Google Drive data 💀

    A new complete 0-click data exfil attack ⛓️‍💥🏴󠁭󠁨󠁴󠁿

    Back in May, OpenAI released a new ChatGPT feature - Connectors.
    Allowing ChatGPT to connect and read your Google Drive, Sharepoint, Notion, and more.

    Problem is, AI can't be trusted.

    Here's how we did it:
    1. Created a malicious document with an invisible prompt injection.
    2. Shared the document with our victim via Google Drive.
    3. Document immediately gets into ChatGPT's context. No user action needed.
    4. Waited for the user to ask ChatGPT to search Google Drive.
    5. ChatGPT sees our document. Searches Google Drive for API keys. Sends them back to our servers.
    6. How can ChatGPT send requests? Simple, by rendering an image onto the screen.

    OpenAI had mitigations in place, but we managed to bypass them. 🤫

    Whatever you do with AI, remember, it's always one step away from completely betraying you 🐍

    Give ChatGPT access to your data at your own risk.

    Kamil RuczynskiKamil Ruczynski • 2ndVerified • 2nd something new in consumer - hiring iOS engineer + designersomething new in consumer - hiring iOS engineer + designer 5mo • 5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Many growth folks are praising Elena Verna’s piece about automating Growth 101. They should. It’s timely and forward-thinking.

    But here’s the part nobody’s saying: Growth isn’t hard because the basics are hard. Growth is hard because most growth leaders have zero actual power.

    • You can’t deliver the “aha” moment faster when your signup flow changes require six Jira tickets and a two-month engineering backlog.
    • You can’t improve first-time experience when product priorities are locked in by a different team.
    • You can’t run high-velocity experiments when you need permission for every pixel.

    Growth is inseparable from product. Period.
    Yet in most companies, it’s treated like an add-on to marketing, a bolt-on function that has to beg for resources.

    The result? Even the best growth leaders spend 80% of their time negotiating for the right to do their jobs, not actually doing them.

    tl;dr: If you’re hiring for growth, set them up to win. Give them product resources, engineering access, and the mandate to actually ship. Otherwise, you’re not hiring for growth, you’re hiring for frustration.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 5mo • 5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    The issue with these automations or the way people present them is that the automation isn't the problem. You can integrate 50 more tools. What matters is specific outcomes.
    That's not time saved (on its own) because I can save time by doing nothing.
    Often the results are plausible but lacking actual logic. Having great context but missing the point. Highly detailed but not useful.
    Agentic AI is really hard. Workflow diagrams are nice but don't conflate them with outcomes.
    David ArnouxDavid Arnoux • 2ndPremium • 2nd Helping GTM Leaders & Founders Grow With GTM x AI | Fractional CxO | Building Linkedin Tools @ humanoidz.aiHelping GTM Leaders & Founders Grow With GTM x AI | Fractional CxO | Building Linkedin Tools @ humanoidz.ai 5mo • 5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    my new favorite flow as product owner of multiple ventures is basically an always-on insight machine. saving hundreds of hours (and details).
    here’s how it works:
    every week, each venture (currently 7) gets at least two real user interviews. on top of that, we pull in synthetic user feedback to simulate hundreds more voices. every conversation is recorded, transcribed, and ready to be processed.
    then the magic happens:
    → the transcripts and synthetic feedback go straight into a product owner agent powered by claude mcp
    → the agent extracts key insights, clusters feedback, and identifies unmet needs
    → it writes feature requests, user stories, and even pulls direct user quotes for context
    → every piece of work is translated into dev-ready kanban cards
    → we also have memory

    from there, claude mcp integrates with notion and automatically populates the weekly sprint boards for each venture.

    the only part still 100% human? the conversations themselves + double-checking cards.

    i spend my time talking to real people, building relationships, and keeping a pulse on our community.

    the rest= summarizing, prioritizing, and formatting...is fully automated.

    before this setup, product ownership was hours of manual backlog grooming, reformatting notes, and chasing clarity between meetings.

    now? it’s instant, consistent, and scalable across ventures.
    this is the future of product work:
     → humans for connection, trust, and judgment
     → agents for synthesis, organization, and execution

    tools in this stack:
    - syntheticusers → synthetic + real feedback at scale
    - granola → instant meeting transcripts
    - claude mcp → product owner automation
    - rag → create memory and consistency
    - notion → sprint + kanban management

    product ownership is becoming less about moving cards around, and more about steering the ship with the clearest, freshest signals possible.

    exciting times...

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 5mo • 5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Most of the "we removed PMs" posts are really about "we removed the roles which were not about product management in the first place, but we still do product management in a top-down approach".

    Andrea SaezAndrea Saez • FollowingVerified • Following Head of PMM @ Turtl 🐢 | Building getforma.co | Author: The Product Momentum Gap |Head of PMM @ Turtl 🐢 | Building getforma.co | Author: The Product Momentum Gap | 5mo • 5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    With GPT-5 coming out, the fear that PMs are becoming redundant is growing.

    But PMs aren’t becoming irrelevant because of AI.

    They’re becoming irrelevant because too many stopped doing the hard parts of the job.

    If your role begins and ends at shipping tickets and validating features, yes… GPT-5 can probably do that better than you.

    Things it can’t do:
    - Uncover unmet needs.
    - Can’t connect user behaviour to business outcomes.
    - It doesn’t know when the problem is actually aligned with the strategy.
    - It has no empathy - not for users, not for stakeholders
    - It doesn’t know how to do proper storytelling or shape a narrative based on context, emotion, or dynamics
    - It cannot synthesize ambiguity into clear action

    Good PMs aren’t scared of GPT-5.
    Bad ones should be, and it’s starting to show.

    Imagine building a hotel where you send a back-of-napkin sketch to an on-site crew you never saw, but heard good things about.

    You stay in touch over the phone, nudging them along.

    "We've successfully completed milestone 1! 🎉" – Hurray, the slab is in place!

    You're like... ok this crew is a bit shady but if I just explain it better over the phone they'll get the job done in no time.

    This is where we are with "I can build [insert whatever] in 24h!".

    It's still truly amazing. The phone is an amazing device. But the level of detachment from reality with some people is absurd.

    𝗧𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗯𝗹𝘂𝗲𝗽𝗿𝗶𝗻𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗮 𝗼𝗻𝗲-𝗺𝗮𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 — 𝗽𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗯𝘆 𝟭𝟬𝟬 𝗔𝗜 𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀.

    Built in Claude Code, this setup turns a single folder into a full-stack AI workforce of 100+ sub-agents. Each agent is a specialized operator — all controllable via natural language: No hiring. No overhead. Just execution.

    𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗶𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀: ⬇️
    Agents are auto-loaded in Claude Code. You describe your task in plain English — and the right agent is triggered. You can also call agents directly by name.

    Examples:
    → “Create a new app for tracking meditation habits” → rapid-prototyper
    → “What’s trending on TikTok we could build?” → trend-researcher
    → “Our reviews are dropping, what’s wrong?” → feedback-synthesizer
    → “Make this screen more fun” → whimsy-injector

    This is pure AgentOps: A complete, self-contained AI workforce — forkable, version-controlled, and context-aware.

    Setup takes 30 seconds. Clone the repo, copy the files into your ~/.claude/agents/ directory, and restart Claude Code.

    Forget the em dash. I think I found the most subtle AI tell.

    "Clarity".

    Which is a pointless observation since everything is AI right now. Especially if you're on LinkedIn.

    Anyway. Why clarity?

    What does it mean?

    I'm having a bit of a double rainbow moment but it is fascinating in ways I can't exactly explain.

    I first noticed when I was vibe coding a tool and ChatGPT called it Clarity. Ok, makes sense. It's a personal finance app that 🥁 brings clarity 🎺.

    But then I started seeing it a bit much.

    📈 Interestingly, Google Search for "clarity" is at the 10-year high. We're at the 100/100 peak right now. Not sure what that means. Are we seeking more clarity? Or is this AI bots seeking clarity themselves?

    I made a board game. A paper one.

    It’s about product management - but actually fun.

    Each player is a Head of Product at a competing company, fighting for users in the same market. You grow your team, focus it on getting and keeping as many subscribers as possible, generate profit, try to keep your CEO and investors happy (good luck with that), and deal with market shifts, trends, and my fav-> the backfires.

    Fun and quick way for people working with or around product to feel how product works and how their own role impacts its success or company profits.

    It simulates the Head of Product job. The more you play, the more insights you get (and the more you might want to hug your HoP).

    I’ll post soon about test plays and pre-orders and all that... For now, I had to share that it exists because it was so much fun and many sleepless nights to make.

    If you want a fun game session with your team, get in touch. Could be a good way to learn, laugh, and suffer together.

    It's called Heads of Product®.
    Or HOP for short.

  • Feed post number 77

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    As much as I love Growth Product, I would only go back to it under one condition.

    That I'm not the first Growth PM in the company. I need to see at least 2 other Growth Product teams.

    Otherwise it's a recipe for burnout.

    – Most startups out there have no idea what Growth PM really does or how to make them successful. They intuitively think you should have at least 7/10 experiment success ratio. That's absurd. Elena Verna set a 50% *failure rate* at Dropbox. Yet people assemble the first ever growth team, tell them to "ship fast" and "experiment" and they want *ResULtS*.

    – A lot of startups add a Growth Product team because advisors or investors told them so, or they read a cool article and think it will solve their revenue problems. It will cost them $400K+ in the first year just to get started and they'll maybe make a fraction of that in revenue.

    – You'll be given KPIs but not necessarily the mandate to experiment as you see fit. You'll work on pricing but not on pricing plans. You'll dig into data but get your experiments killed on anecdotal evidence. This clash of cultures will slow you down as you still work in traditional PM frameworks but are expected to "deliver growth". Quarterly roadmaps, an occasional "little project on the side", rabbit whole refactors...

    – Your team will be assembled from random engineers who may be a completely wrong fit. Growth Engineers are special. Unicorns even. People think they hire a Growth PM, give them some mix of FE/BE engineers and they're ready to go. Wrong. This is a major point of failure and why it will take a year to just get into the zone.

    – You'll have constant pressure to deliver. This hamster wheel can be draining, especially considering the above point. When you have engineers *WaItiNg FoR TicKEtS* it is a burnout time bomb.

    – When sh*t hits the fan, all of this will become evident, as you'll be at the top of the list. Which makes sense actually and has nothing to do with you. It is the completely wrong expectations, zero company preparedness for what Growth Product is, zero culture fit that shouldn't have even lead to you being hired.

    If you're that first Growth PM, good luck.

    hashtag#realism hashtag#productmanagementtruthbombs hashtag#product

    - Marketing: Increase personalization, and improve efficiency across the content supply chain. Reduce content creation costs by up to 40%

Feel free to contact me. 1yr • Edited • 1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Dumb Product Manager Interview Questions
    ----------------

    A short rant here. I see people recommending questions to ask PM candidates to understand their thinking process and assess their skills. e.g. one question that is often recommended looks something like:

    𝗜𝗺𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂’𝗿𝗲 𝗮 𝗣𝗠 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗦𝗽𝗼𝘁𝗶𝗳𝘆. 𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝘄𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘂𝗲 𝟱𝘅 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗻𝗲𝘅𝘁 𝟱 𝘆𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘀?

    There are many blog posts on PM sites that propose this exact question. Google it. To be honest, I dislike questions like this. They're pointless and of virtually zero value.

    As much as some Director or VP PM might believe this is going to help them assess that candidate, it won't. Even Daniel Ek (Spotify CEO) can't answer this question.

    First of all....Spotify revenues double roughly every five years. They don't 5X. See the chart below. So the question is stupid on it's face.

    Second, whatever "logical" arguments the candidate makes are based on zero analysis and zero understanding of the realities, complexities and challenges Spotify (or any other company) is facing.

    Third, there is so much subjectivity and bias built into how ANY response ANY candidate gives would be evaluated, that the "discussion" that ensues with the candidate is more likely to harm them than help.

    e.g. if the candidate doesn't know much about Spotify or is the kind of person who actually wants to have data and understanding about a topic before answering - i.e. the kind of candidate you probably want on your team - they'll often perform terribly in this situation.

    And whether it is Spotify or some other company (Apple, Tesla, Facebook, Dyson etc), it doesn't matter.

    If the same question was posed about Apple at the height of their iPod/iTunes era (when Blackberry was king of the smart phones), would ANYONE have said, build a revolutionary smart phone that will own 60% of the entire smart phone market, destroy Blackberry, and drive over 50% of Apple's revenue?

    And if they did, what do you think the interviewer would have thought of that answer?

    So let's stop asking these kinds of questions, and be more thoughtful and diligent in our hiring processes. Let's use questions that actually assess important attributes of the candidates we interview. We owe them that much. And it will only benefit ourselves as Product Leaders and our companies.

    P.S. I have some views on take home interview exercises as well. 😀

    Great advice. Some additions:

    – This is true even when presenting iterations 2, 3, 5. Remind the audience what the goal was, what previous iterations tried to address etc.

    – This is (naturally) also true for Product management, Marketing, Customer success... Connect the audience to the business goals and provide clarity. Lead up to your solution and don't just describe the spec of "what" you're doing or building.

    – When presenting to outside functions, make sure to speak their language too. They may not intuitively know your jargon. Remember a sales presentation with their 20 acronyms? Translate for the audience in terms they understand.
    Jeff WhiteJeff White • 2ndPremium • 2nd Improving Medtech software ➤ Advancing UX careers with storytelling @ uxstorytelling.io ➤ UX Consultant ➤ UX Designer & EducatorImproving Medtech software ➤ Advancing UX careers with storytelling @ uxstorytelling.io ➤ UX Consultant ➤ UX Designer & Educator 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    This is how you lose a room of stakeholders when you present:

    “On this screen I used a list view, with a search box & filters on top.”

    Do this instead:

    “System admins struggle to find specific users so they can change their permissions. They’re in a rush and it’s a needle in a haystack: 50% of our customers have more than 10,000 users in their system.

    We’re going to keep missing our SUS score goal without a fix here. This issue brought our scores down below 80 for the first time in a year.

    This new search and filter design makes it twice as fast to narrow down—and the list view now shows enough data to confirm they’ve found the right user without clicking into the detail sheet”.

    Boom 🎉

    In the first example the designer describes the interface to us.

    In the second they tell a story.

    Stop describing UI and features to stakeholders.

    Start telling a story to help them understand why the design is good.

    For better products and better design reviews focus on outcomes.

    Not outputs.

    Explaining product quality to someone who ultimately doesn't believe in the importance of craft is probably the hardest problem.

    My friend was once desperately trying to get a rational answer to "why does this painting resonate with you so much? What is *objectively* good in it to be called art?".

    I learned to escape these conversations very fast. There's no way you can explain art to someone who's trapped in their brain. It's not you, it's them.

    I've had similar discussions with leaders about design. "I don't think good design matters so much". They would point to poor-looking competition from public companies that IPO'd years ago. Or underappreciate the simplicity and product quality of more relatable competition today. "Their design is really nothing special".

    Ultimately, it cannot be explained but it can be measured. Just not with the same lagging indicators people think design should be measured. And if you don't care much about the leading indicators of quality, then that's your call.
    Karri SaarinenKarri Saarinen • 3rd+Premium • 3rd+ Co-Founder, CEO at LinearCo-Founder, CEO at Linear 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    What I talked about at Stripe Sessions:

    Craft and Quality, and professional grade software at     Linear

    To me craft is mindset, and quality is the output.

    If you think of anything that was built or created, and well done, it’s probably because they cared and they knew their craft. They designed it well. They chose the right materials. They built it well. It’s very easy to see when the person doesn't care. The work is sloppy. There are mistakes. It works and likely breaks down very quickly.

    I think as a software industry the past decade we kind of forgot the craft. More stuff look like something where people didn’t care about the craft. We focused on building larger teams. We then made them run like factories churning out new things at a consistent pace. We validated “quality” by A/B testing and looking at metrics. Software today borderline works.

    But we are supposed to be professionals and real companies. We’re selling products to people to buy. I think our responsibility is to deliver good products and quality products, not something that is sloppy.

    Craft is the mindset that creates quality. But it’s not enough. You need to have the right skills and ideas. You need individuals who take their profession and craft seriously, then build teams that work this way together, and have a company that creates for it. Not only incentivizing with deadlines and metrics, but also caring if the experience is good enough.

    Especially professional software should be “professional grade”. Professional grade tools and appliances are often more durable, more powerful, more precise and focused. Professional grade software should be that way too. It should be more or less bug free. It should be fast. It should meet the needs of the customers.

    The pushback is always “well how do you measure quality”. There isn’t an easy answer or a single measurement, it’s going to be hard, but it is possible. You first have to believe in it, then encourage teams to do it, and the way you validate is by listening to what the market and customers say.

    For us Linear it’s always been anecdotal. Linear is used daily in the companies and we hear a lot of feedback. They send notes how great the product or a new feature is. People tweet about it. CEO/founders sometimes tell me that they picked Linear because the product experience is so good that they use it to inspire their teams to do the same. VCs tell me how their portfolio companies rave about Linear and bring it up in the conversations.

    As you listen to these signals, you start to see if the quality is there or not. But even when you hear the signals, you can’t stop. Great products require consistent, daily effort keeping the quality.
    In short, people aren’t organically raving about your product, you probably don’t have a great product yet. Maybe you have just an OK product. If you have a great product, people will talk about it.

    Great products create fans and champions. In my mind product quality is the ultimate moat.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    "Just focus on your customer feedback and iterate!" Yes, but...

    – Are you sure they are the right customer?
    – Are you sure you are innovating and not optimising for little gain?
    – Are you ready to give up on parts of your product that they have no use for?
    – Are your fundamentals in place for that customer, like the pricing structure, GTM?
    – Are you effectively going towards a dead-end?

    Being hyper focused on customer satisfaction only makes sense if you have the right customer for your business. Easier said than done.

    The costs of prioritising feedback purely because it's coming from paying customers can be fatal. (Financially!)

    You follow the feedback, you objectively improve the product for the use case, yet growth has stalled.

    You can still innovate from customer feedback but you need people who can see the patterns, and balance immediate action with making an outsized impact. Asking (and thinking, a lot) "why" helps. Good product intuition as well.
