    Things not adding up? Struggling with incoherence? Welcome to professional Everything Everywhere All at Once.

    The Hope 🦄
    On one hand, we're hearing things that inspire and give hope. A call for courageous leaders who get into the details in all the right ways, empower teams, and have the potential to improve our organizations. Agency, connecting with customers, seeing the impact of our work. Focusing on outcomes instead of outputs. The potential of AI.

    All of these things speak to purpose, hope, possibilities, and opportunities. They talk about fulfillment, career enhancement, and purpose.

    The Reality (For Many) 🔥
    Multiple rounds of layoffs (amidst record profits). Truly hurtful hiring practices ("Oh whoops, we've decided to restructure, offer rescinded, thanks for the 3hr assignment"). Thoughtless RTO mandates. Same old corporate doublespeak in all companies—startups, 100y enterprises, and everything in between. Tech CEOs are saying dumb, insensitive things that are so predictably biased that it hurts to listen. Gaslighting is in full effect.

    A rapidly declining sense of loyalty in companies. We're still working through the trauma of the pandemic. The climate change news is terrifying. Global conflict. A reported epidemic of loneliness (here in the US).

    We're bombarded by a full range of perspectives on AI, from blind AI fan-boy enthusiasm all the way to complete Luddism and genuine fear for jobs and everything in between. Across the spectrum of companies, regardless of maturity, we're hearing about things that are not good, or at least not as good as we thought (or wanted to believe).

    The Advice... 🔇
    And then you have people dealing with all this in their own way or trying to help others,
    -Give them a version of harsh truth / tough love in an effort to help.
    -Help them be more resilient, accepting, and pragmatic.
    -Support their job search and analyze the current job market. Discuss how roles will change or not change.
    -Urge people to adapt their skills and encourage companies to transform.

    They are all doing what people do for the most part, which is trying to help in their own way. But sometimes it isn't landing. There's a deluge of coping advice.

    My realization… 🤔
    People are tired. People feel in limbo. People are questioning themselves, their companies, and their craft. It's not the rate of change that is truly gripping people, it is the tension of the change.

    It is crucial to be empathetic, sensitive, and helpful in genuine ways. Our default ways of helping may not even be helpful right now, so it's important to be super self-aware. We all need someone to listen and not lecture.

    I've written, taught, spoken, and drawn infographics for many years about good products, high-performing teams, feature factories, and continuous improvement. It's my thing, I guess. In the last couple weeks I've had the time to connect with so many friends and hear about what's going on in people's heads lately.

    Things are tough.

    Be kind.

    I thought I had to understand and enjoy abstract level systems thinking to appear smart.

    I'm over it. 👋

    While I appreciate people who feel great about debating the theories of complexity, networks, dynamic systems and whatnot, I'm OK being a bit below.

    That doesn't mean people like me don't think about systems.

    I think about:

    – How one customer problem connects (or doesn't connect) to other problems.
    – How one product strategy impacts our product positioning or sales or customer success.
    – How investing in one area of product effectively impacts both the customers who use it, and customers who don't.
    – How executing on a vision needs a series of interconnected systems and how they might evolve from the early stages and into the future.
    – How revenue is the butterfly that solves all problems. (OK I just made that up but we can debate if you want!)

    And many more.

    Yet I may not really join discussions on how "everything that is happening" can be explain by some chaos theory.

    Or how organisational problems can be observed through the lens of [insert a lvl 99 abstract theory from the 1950s].

    Or how every problem can be summarised as a [X] problem.

    I stopped expecting that these things must at least somehow interest me. I think it was FOMO or some feeling of 'I need to do better'. Better being, more theoretical, more unreachable to the rest. Gross – but hey that's just me.

    I'm perfectly fine here at lvl 7.25. Being abstract enough to bring clarity to the "local chaos", but not so abstract that I feed on the chaos. If that even makes sense.

    If you've felt the same, let me know. I'm here to tell you – there's so much value across the full spectrum of abstraction in what we do. It all matters. Don't force yourself where you don't feel like you belong. It's OK.

    =====
    Looking for a lvl 7.25 systems thinker PM? (aiming for 7.8 this year 🤞)
    Ping me.

    Leah TharinLeah Tharin • FollowingPremium • Following B2B Product & Growth - leahtharin.comB2B Product & Growth - leahtharin.com 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Let's hate on one of the most useless metrics on a Thursday once more: The NPS. -> You can absolutely love a product, and even recommend it but hate individual features about it.

    The final number doesn't 'mean' anything. What should I do with an NPS of 40? Use the CES (Customer Effort Score or CSAT) instead:

    Asking hypothetical questions (Would you recommend...) is inherently risky for predictability. The CES asks how easy something was immediately after it happened, examining an event that has already happened.

    Asking on a feature level like that gives you targeted feedback about a very specific tool or feature. A team can get two useful insights from this: An average score that means something and splitting it up by vote.

    You can then see what unites people who voted a 1 compared to those who voted a 5. Are they using the tool differently? Are they a completely different segment? Is it a tool that people are indifferent about? (Big Middle-finger pattern) or something that people hate or love (Strong 1 and 5 distribution)

    You also can in house compare different CES scores of different tools. This is simply not possible if you use the NPS unless you have something like a course platform where they rate one-time consumed products like a course or a book.


    How to implement

    The CES is best asked right after a success happened with a tool. A download, something was saved, do NOT interrupt the flow of the user before they completed the action.

    Since the CES is triggered on a feature level, you need to be careful not to trigger it too much. I recommend asking for it not more than once per 30 days/user, but this depends on your product and might even be way too much for high-usage products.

    A comment field is optional, and the CES as well. Do not force users to answer it. Make it easy to dismiss (x) and capture "ESC" as a hotkey and click outside of it.

    Good ways to segment the CES Results if you have the data:

    Every CES score is per feature and:
    - Free vs Trial vs Customers
    - Different ICPs
    - Geography


    Give NPS no chance. Use actual data.

    Andifyoustilluseitbringanothermetricfastthx

    Chase WarringtonChase Warrington • FollowingInfluencer • Following Head of Operations at Doist | LinkedIn Top Voice | Global Top 20 Future of Work Leader | Host of About Abroad Podcast | Forbes Business Council | Modern Workplace Advisor, Writer, & SpeakerHead of Operations at Doist | LinkedIn Top Voice | Global Top 20 Future of Work Leader | Host of About Abroad Podcast | Forbes Business Council | Modern Workplace Advisor, Writer, & Speaker 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    It's wild to me that we're still having this conversation, but remote ≠ remote-only. Investing in high-quality in-person time is a critical aspect of every successful distributed team I'm aware of, and yet, I continue to hear this...

    A COO recently challenged me on our investment in co-located team gatherings (retreats/offsites), citing that this goes against our remote-first approach to teamwork and that the high costs of bringing people together surely produce a negative ROI.

    I responded by sharing some data from a recent survey, where my teammates reported the following after attending an offsite:

    - 92% felt more connected to their teammates
    - 94% felt more aligned with our vision and path forward as a company
    - 95% felt more enthusiastic about working for Doist

    If that's not worth investing in then I'm not sure what is - but I can guarantee ping-pong tables and happy hours won't achieve those results.

    He was still not convinced, so we went deeper and calculated the actual tangible costs:

    - He's spending $11k/person/year on office space that is 60% occupied, while his team is begging for more flexibility and to lift the mandate on in-office days.

    - We're spending $4000/person/year bringing our fully remote team to retreats attended by 95% of our employees, and who have voted almost unanimously that location independence + 2-3 meetups per year is ideal for their productivity and work-life balance.

    This was before we got into employee attrition rates, re-hiring costs, access to global talent, and satisfaction/engagement scores.

    But still, offering remote work + team gatherings is "too expensive."

    Help me out people - make it make sense 😅

    Moses Maurice MugerwaMoses Maurice Mugerwa • 2ndVerified • 2nd Operations Executive | Business Growth, Strategy & Market Expansion | I Help Global and Early-Stage Companies Build Efficient, Scalable Operations Across AfricaOperations Executive | Business Growth, Strategy & Market Expansion | I Help Global and Early-Stage Companies Build Efficient, Scalable Operations Across Africa 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Stop looking at Africa as a continent with 'cheap labor'...

    Compensation was never intended to punish people for where they live, but to reward people for the value they bring regardless of where they are based.

    During my time consulting with early-stage global companies outside Africa who wish to scale into     hashtag#Africa.

    There are instances when potential clients would ask for my piece rate or time rate, clients would go like...

    "But you are based in Africa, why would you charge this much?"

    "Someone in London charges right around the same"

    Such statements were usually a signal that may not manage to work with a client.

    I totally understand the mini-variations that should happen in compensation because of the difference in the cost of living indices.

    However, shame upon people who simply think that living in Africa should be a green card to earning low.

    "....there's cheap labor in Africa."

    This is a slavery mindset.

    Many of us don't have a say in where we live, but we have a big say in how valuable we are.

    Our value is more than global...

    We can do what anyone else in the world can do.

    And to get to this point, it has taken time, effort, and money.

    We've enrolled for global first-class training...
    We've built global personal brands...
    We've attained global experience working with global brands...

    The above has cost us.

    Global courses charge us all the same regardless of where we are based.

    Don't tell us global, we know what global is.

    Hey, it's not our fault...

    Not our fault that our accommodation or meals are relatively cheaper, I mean, Africa is gifted.

    My point is - Pay for value, don't pay for origin of value.

    On the flip side, here are a few tips I have learned and employed around defending your price as an African.

    1️⃣ Reframing the Conversation.

    Always shift the focus from geography to expertise and results.

    Emphasize the tangible benefits of your services and how they align with the client's goals.

    2️⃣ Providing Comparative Insights.

    Offer insights into industry standards and rates for similar services globally.

    Show how your pricing aligns with the market and is competitive based on the value delivered.

    3️⃣ Emphasize Quality Over Cost.

    Stress the importance of quality and reliability in service delivery.

    Position yourself as a strategic partner focused on delivering exceptional results, rather than simply offering lower costs.

    4️⃣ Offer Flexible Solutions.

    Be open to exploring flexible pricing structures that reflect the unique needs and constraints of the lead while ensuring fair compensation for your expertise.

    5️⃣ Build Trust Through Transparency.

    Foster trust by being transparent about your pricing rationale and the value proposition behind it.

    Demonstrate your commitment to fairness and mutual success.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    "Synthetic user research" is a hot-take zone. See more with caution.

    First things first, both synthetic data and simulations are known and widely used concepts in research. Dismissing synthetic research simply as "BS research" is an overreaction unless we talk about the underlying data first.

    At the same time, GenAI practitioners (often people with little or no user research experience) can get overly excited by the prospect of just prompting an LLM and getting something convincing in return. Cool story, but not actionable user research.

    𝗕𝗼𝘁𝗵 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗲𝘅𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗺𝗲𝘀.

    The sweet middle point is what I find interesting.

    Fine-tuning a model with a large enough corpus of customer data teaches the model the nuance of what *your* customers say and do. Sales calls, customer interviews, surveys, key behavioural data, G2 reviews etc.

    Incorporating Retrieval-Augmented Generation systems allows for real-time access to customer data, which also decreases hallucination and increases relevance of the model.

    Continually testing the model for bias and accuracy gives some level of quality control. LLM testing and monitoring tools are emerging in this space.

    So now imagine a model or models that are fine tuned on all that local data, monitored for accuracy and bias, accessible to everyone in the company. Is running simulations a crazy idea? Probably not, but we don't know yet.

    𝗦𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗲𝘅𝘁𝗿𝗮 𝘁𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵𝘁𝘀:

    – Why do this even? Why not just hire researchers?

    – What would the sweet spot be between researchers who command these models and size of the organisation?

    – Orchestrating the entire stack, teaching people new skills and changing processes are all high risk for most companies. Off the shelf tools will likely suck for a while more.

    – Is calling it a "synthetic" user research the right taxonomy if it's fine tuned to local data? Probably is, due to generative nature but is that the strongest argument?

    – This is already a part of the product strategy for many tools that process customer data. We're early, but combining all that data into a "user research bot" isn't far-fetched – it's coming. Sorry if that's triggering. Will it really work? Maybe... maybe not.

    – While LLM bias is real, so is our human bias too. Have you tried addressing it first? Yeah, it's hard.

    – Why is synthetic data on top of language statistics different to synthetic data on top of e.g. healthcare patient data statistics? Largely due to lack of transparency and control. What if we regained (some of) transparency and control with future niche open source models and tooling?

    Just to be clear: I don't think at this point anyone is going to be replaced with this. But the tech has a potential to address some known problems for product teams. (Stale personas anyone? No UXRs anyone? Difficult access to customer data anyone? A *ton* of customer bias among the teams anyone!?)

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    I can’t think of a more ethical goal for hiring tools than reducing the information asymmetry.

    Company vs applicant access to information is wildly disproportionate.

    Company knows:
    – The number of applicants
    – The number of applicants moved to the next stage
    – The actual state of the process (still considering after 4 weeks?)
    – Whether an ATS is used and if so, which one
    – The results from the ATS
    – The reasons for rejections
    – The criteria used to dismiss candidates not present in the JD
    – Whether the application was ever in front of a real person
    – Internal notes from everyone involved in the process
    – Probably dozens of other pieces of information.

    Candidate knows, at average:
    – That they were rejected

    Candidate knows, best case:
    – A categorical feedback for rejection (salary, industry match, experience level)

    Transparency starts with hiring.

    If you're building in this space, be the change. Be the PM who says "we don't have many customers asking for this, yet it is where we want to take the industry".

    You can do this. I'm happy to chat about some ideas or be your guinea pig. hashtag#bethechange hashtag#hiringasymmetry

    One of my new pet peeves when it comes to PM hiring is Years of Experience in Industry or Category™️.

    Lots of problems with it:

    – Not a good indicator of PM quality.
    – Not a guarantee the PM will be able to transfer previous context successfully.
    – Your context is likely different. Types of problems, ICPs, growth stage, product culture… The “match” is superficial.
    – Too much of industry experience can develop into tunnel vision. Yikes.

    More importantly, if you make that a job requirement, it signals your poor understanding of what makes a PM successful. You’re missing out on good candidates.

    Perhaps you’d rather want to check on:

    – Do they think from first principles?
    – Can they creatively tackle ambiguous new challenges?
    – Are they an active, open-minded learner?
    – …

    I get it, you want a quick proxy measure that gives you a piece of mind. But know that your product is changing. Disruption is around the corner. What you think you know about your market may not be relevant in a year.

    You need curious, empathetic, well rounded PMs. Hire for that. Not for a category match.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Leading the first product growth team is the hardest job of all.

    Mainly because in most people's minds, your job is to run experiments where the majority should be successful in increasing a metric.

    10 experiments = at least 7 times you moved a KPI up and to the right. Other times you were slightly less successful or "didn't move the needle".

    Ironically, you could be a team that ships a volume of features, never evaluates your success other than "it's shipped", and be less of a candidate for layoffs than a growth product team that misses its targets.

    Here's an example:

    𝗧𝗮𝗿𝗴𝗲𝘁: increase the adoption of a feature to at least X WAU.
    𝗥𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗹𝘁: you got to 5% of the target.
    𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴: The adoption requires access to the buyer persona and they're not using the app frequently at all and we also don't have a good way to segment them since the data is missing or corrupt.

    Success or failure?

    𝗠𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲: 🚨 The growth product team underperformed by 95%. FAIL.
    𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘄𝘁𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲: 🟢 The growth team gained a critical insight that will redefine their future experiments, help them focus on the right channels to reach buyers, introduce better segmentation and avoid wasting time in future. WIN.

    While being successful at the KPI targets is still the ultimate goal, the foundation of product growth needs to be set first. Access to data, one or two proven growth loops, user segmentation, data quality etc. Ideally this is in place even before you hire the first team.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    "Freemium products are better products."

    This is one of the (many) insights from Lenny Rachitsky's interview with Jason M. Lemkin that I wanted to highlight.

    While freemium comes with its own set of problems especially if you have no strategy on what to do with free users (user-generated content, reviews, path to upgrade etc), it's still true that the free plan forces you to improve quality in a few aspects:

    – Self serve onboarding. Can users experience value without being hand-held by customer success? Is the product intuitive to new users? Can they set up their accounts and be successful on day 1? How does the product support both simple and complex use cases, and different use cases altogether?

    – Self serve help. Can people learn about features and configurations on their own? Is documentation accessible and comprehensive? Are there contextual help mechanisms to help users out if they are stuck? What about user guides or "Academy" for long-tail outcomes?

    Even if you don't go for freemium, you can adopt aspects of self-serve as a way to improve product quality across the board. It makes your sales-led onboarding easier, helps you scale, helps retain and make customers happy.

    ---

    At aleno this was practically my entire mission: make the product more self-serve to improve quality, reduce the customer success effort and contribute to sustainable company growth. It takes a strong cross-functional effort, customer centricity, design and more.

  • Feed post number 103

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • Edited • 1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    There’s a high probability you’ll want to implement a Q&A AI bot this year. Here’s how I would prepare:

    – 𝐄𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐭𝐞𝐚𝐦 𝐨𝐧 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐑𝐞𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐚𝐥-𝐀𝐮𝐠𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐆𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤𝐬.
    People hear all kinds of chat bot horror stories which gets them to think of AI bots as LLM black boxes. When your team doesn’t understand the underlying technology, it makes it hard to debug and fix problems. RAG ≠ speaking to raw LLM.

    – [𝐇𝐨𝐭 𝐭𝐚𝐤𝐞] 𝐆𝐞𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐞𝐧𝐠𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐚 𝐬𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞 𝐑𝐀𝐆 𝐛𝐨𝐭 𝐥𝐨𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲.
    There’s no better way to understand RAG than to build it. Don’t build the whole large scale pipeline. Copy a few of your articles into .txt files. Reuse a starter script from Supabase or LangChain. (Links in comments) This should not take more than a few days for a single engineer and they will be able to tweak everything from the embeddings model, vector index, similarity, and most importantly have the full insight into how an article is split, vectorised, searched, fed to the LLM. This person will now understand how to evaluate different tools, debug them, improve articles etc.

    – 𝐃𝐞𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐩𝐥𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐞𝐟𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐭 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐦 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐀𝐈 𝐛𝐨𝐭 𝐞𝐟𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐭.
    We decided to both rebuild the knowledge base AND implement and test the bot at the same time at aleno. The benefit is that there’s more of pressure to rewrite articles since you have a set deadline to deploy the bot. However, this coupling makes things more complex, especially if you don’t already have a good content process/pipeline. Assess your content first. Stage 1, focus on improving it since it will take a lot of effort. Then stage 2 build the bot and focus on refining the content while testing for different questions.

    – 𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐞 𝐚 𝐭𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐞𝐭 𝐨𝐟 𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬.
    This is hard because there’s lots of unknown unknowns. For example, minor rewording of questions will give different results. Or question in one language gives a great answer, but gives no answer in another language. (Is your content multi-lingual? Good luck!)

    – 𝐃𝐨𝐧'𝐭 𝐬𝐞𝐭𝐭𝐥𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐟𝐥𝐨𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐛𝐮𝐭𝐭𝐨𝐧.
    The default interaction is to have a chat-like Floating Action Button in the corner. Is this the best mental model? I'm not sure. People rarely like to chat with support. I like what Dopt (acquired by Airtable) is exploring in this space. The command palette is an interesting pattern to try too. (Notion, Command AI (fka CommandBar)) Don’t fall for the chat FAB being the best you can do.

    Truth is, you are not ready for this. 😅

    But the potential is really interesting.

    —

    If you’re building in this space and looking for a UX-minded, code-tinkering PM, I'm available. Next post I think I’ll explore some ideas of how Q&A products might help teams set up, test and deploy bots with more success. Follow if you like!

    As I’m leaving my current role at Aleno, I wanted to reflect on a few things we accomplished during my time.

    My mission was to demonstrate how a strongly sales-led organisation can benefit from adopting aspects of a self-serve product experience. The long game was a path towards Product-Led Sales. (hashtag#PLS)

    – In one instance, we added integration nudges to key contextual places in the app. This increased the # of leads for an integration from ~1/week to about 6/week. We turned it from a mostly outbound motion to inbound – with new leads coming in almost daily.

    – In another instance I turned a manual, customer success-heavy process into a completely self-serve one. It exposed a revenue-generating feature to ~15x more people while completely removing the manual workload of enabling it. Cool thing? It was way easier than I thought.

    – I also put my UX hat on to prototype a complete revamp of the reservation user flow. I combined internal insights, data and some good old design experience to overcome years of design debt, and then validated it with in-person usability tests in Munich.

    – I learned a ton about retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) as we integrated a Q&A bot. I love tinkering with GenAI and so exploring the ins and outs of RAG was fun. I'll post more about this too.

    My big takeaway is just how interesting the path towards Product-Led Sales is. It’s hard, it takes breaking down silos, it touches down on every aspect of how the organisation works, how it builds and how it thinks about interacting with customers. It’s a marathon, with learning points all along the way.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Legacy product debt can sink the company because...

    – It corrupts the culture, as people get incredibly attached to "it has to work like this" even in spite of the market signaling differently.

    – It puts lots of pressure on customer support, as documentation usually lags behind and old features have not gotten any improvements.

    – This puts a scaling pressure and makes it hard to improve Revenue per Employee. If you need to hire more support to onboard more customers, good luck with growth.

    – It makes new tech adoption harder because purely technical refactors are not going to be prioritised. This may or may not be significant to your case, but does limit your options.

    There's so many side effects of just pushing out feature after feature and not truly looking back. But why does this problem even exist if addressing it comes with so many benefits?

    – It seems risky to remove features as there's always someone using them,
    – It seems risky to have bigger revamps since you already "can" sell what you have or at least that's what you believe,
    – There's so many small tweaks you could do, so it sounds right to address those (50 little changes) first before doing anything big and risky.
    – Bigger changes are easy to dismiss when they seem "way too big, 1 year to build at least".

    When you let poor product practice creep in, eventually it slows you down and it gets harder and harder to stay competitive. Until one day it's too late.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    I love my product brief templates but there's a fatal flaw: creating briefs only when you have a solution in mind.

    Typically, briefs are split into a problem/opportunity section and a solution section. So far so good. 💪

    Until it turns out you only create product briefs when you are set on a specific solution.

    This can lead to a few problems:

    – You waste time back-filling the brief with the problem section. Unless the problem space can challenge that one specific solution, why waste everyone's time?

    – If you're lucky, the team will question your problem space. But if you're set on a solution this will be an awkward discussion.

    – You hurt the trust between Product and other functions when your brief becomes fluff. You may not see it, but it will happen.

    You can see this when the Jobs To Be Done is just a rephrased user story. When the Data / Insights section is consistently empty or contains fluff such as "we have observed that [...]". Or when people simply remove entire sections from the brief. ✨

    In my experience this can easily happen when there's a disconnect between an aspirational state of the product culture and where it really is in practice. The brief is where you want to be, but it's not enough to get there.

    I don't have a tested solution here but some thoughts:

    – Create briefs before you have a solution. This is tough to impossible depending on the setting since problem statements often circulate in the hallways. No one says "that's a great problem, let's collect all we know about it in one place". It floats around until some people agree on solutions, and then it goes into the brief. (Lack of UXRs anyone?)

    – Split the briefs into two separate documents: "Problem/Opportunity Brief" and "Solution Brief". Might be perceived as "too much process" depending on the context.

    – Take an unbiased look into your discovery process. Do you just take one or two comments from support to prioritise a feature? Is your team empowered to participate in some way, or do they just wait for tickets? A formal brief in an informal setting won't be enough to nudge the culture in the direction you want.

    – Be OK with some solutions not needing a lot of discovery. Don't back-fill with fluff, just explain as it is. If the opportunity is to build a team invitation system, a common table-stakes B2B feature, perhaps it doesn't need as much discovery as "Use GenAI to make our customers 20x efficient".

    Have you seen or contributed to fluffy product briefs too? Designers and Engineers, looking at you. Do you feel that the problem space is just theatre play to satisfy a template or make the PM feel smart? Been there, done that. 😬

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    A nice little probe into customer centricity is what is considered a bug. Is something that clearly works against customer expectations, but works "as specced" long time ago a bug or a new feature request?

    Typically, it's not a bug – it works as expected. All good! 💪 No one to blame! ⭐️ It's just a new feature request, add it to the backlog! 🙏

    But what does "it works as expected" mean? Expected by whom?

    The person who wrote the requirement 2 years ago and never validated it before or after?

    Or expected by customers who pay for your product?

    I'd argue that a feature that consistently undermines user experience is a bug regardless of how the feature got built in the first place. It was certainly built with the best of intentions.

    Purists, I'm all yours! ✝

    The reason I think about this as a small – you can argue irrelevant – measure of customer centricity is because of who you put in the centre of the discussion. The developer/PM/designer/CEO who put the feature in place originally, or the customer who's trying to use it today?

  • Feed post number 109

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 1yr • 1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    I've seen UXRs say that they are the only ones qualified to do research. Need to learn something about your customers? Unless you have UXRs apparently you will never be able to learn it! 🤷‍♀️

    This sort of elitism damages the field of research.

    I'm not saying we don't need researchers. I've seen many many problems where leaders believe that research is just taking sales/support feedback and figuring out what to build. Or people extracting fractional % distributions from a sample of 14. Or saying "we know what we need to build" and piling up the product debt. Or missing obvious threads between screens and features that a researcher would connect easily.

    This can be super frustrating to a UXD turned PM. Challenging the status quo is often met with "let's not get into analysis paralysis" (after barely scratching the surface).

    The problem however isn't the lack of full-time UXR people on the team.

    The problem also isn't collaborative discovery.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    They didn't add friction, they removed it. People think that each "click" is friction. Each step is friction. That's only true if the step feels confusing, unnecessary, unhelpful and that it leads the user away from the perceived, desired outcome.

    If each step helps answer one question or doubt, and if the trajectory of steps feels to be aligned with the user's desired outcome (e.g. learning how to save money) then it actually removes friction.

    This is why I freak out a bit when someone says "that is more clicks".
    Matt LernerMatt Lerner • 2ndInfluencer • 2nd Founder @ SYSTM, Ex PayPal, 500 Startups VCFounder @ SYSTM, Ex PayPal, 500 Startups VC 2yr • Edited • 2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    StepLadder grew 11X in 1 year by 𝘢𝘥𝘥𝘪𝘯𝘨 friction to their funnel.
    Here's how...

    With degrees from Wharton, Stanford and Oxford, plus 20 years in business and a previous startup,     Matthew Addison and Lucy Mullins, did not lack brains or experience.

    Still, their startup was not growing, and nothing seemed to work.

    Their company Circles powered by StepLadder helps people save, together, to reach their financial goals faster.

    “𝗡𝗼𝗽𝗮𝗱𝗼𝗻 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗱 𝘂𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗰𝘂𝘀"
    "The first thing we did in the SYSTM program was find our 'rate-limiting step,'  so we would know where to focus for the greatest impact,” Addison explained.

    “We realised our bottleneck was in the middle of the funnel.

    “Getting signups was easy, the hard part was getting people to actually commit and save money each month.”

    “We tried simplifying the flows, testing motivational emails, nothing worked."

    𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝗶𝗲𝗰𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗽𝘂𝘇𝘇𝗹𝗲
    “Nopadon kept asking us 'what was holding them back?’ We couldn't improve activation until we understood why people weren't saving in the first place. Deleting form fields and turning buttons green wasn’t working.”

    "We interviewed customers and uncovered many blockers."

    "At each stage of the process, our customers had specific doubts and questions. We actually had good answers for all these questions, but we weren’t providing them.”

    "We started testing changes based on what we were hearing from customers."

    𝗙𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝘄𝗮𝘀 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗳𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗱 - 𝟭𝟬𝗫 𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻
    “To fix this, we actually added friction to the funnel. We added steps and questions to address customer doubts. Noom does this too, their signup is like 20 screens long, but those questions answer doubts and build intent.”

    “Our flows got longer, but they got better. Conversion to active eventually increased from 3% to 30%. That’s not a typo.”

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    What often freaks engineers out is the idea of time allotment. This is where at the start of the quarter I take our planned initiatives and allocate certain amount of time for each.

    "How can you estimate the time we need to build this if even we don't know!?"

    It's not a time estimate though. It's a time investment.

    Every quarter you get around 12 weeks to invest into different bets. A problem with just going at it one at a time is that you lose a sense of time and can easily overspend on an initiative, pushing other ones out of the quarter. This creates a mess for the following quarter, and damages morale.

    I learned this way back in art classes. Your paper is the space you operate in (a quarter in our case).
    If you start drawing a sitting person by
    detailing the nose,
    then the eye,
    then the neck,
    and the body,
    by the time you get to the leg you'll realise it won't fit.
    And you kinda wanted the leg too.

    That's why you sketch it first in broad strokes – you allocate roughly where things should go and how much space they need.

    I hadn't really seen this before and thought I was improvising a process too much, but then I found it's also at the core of Shape Up by Ryan Singer, and has a better name: appetite.

    "When shaping, we focus less on estimates and more on our appetite. Instead of asking how much time it will take to do some work, we ask: How much time do we want to spend? How much is this idea worth?"
    https://lnkd.in/dgrQxUE7

    A drawback is that it is top-down: you define a solution, shape it up in broad strokes and hand off to the team. The team can still figure out the details but they don't choose the opportunities themselves. This may or may not align with your goals, but if you have a set of bets, it's a good way to sketch your way through a quarter and not lose a leg.

    hashtag#product hashtag#productmanagement hashtag#shapeup

    The goal of transcribing customer calls is of course to document and extract insights in ways better than you can do manually:

    - Get actual quotes to enrich your personas, user stories, or just share vivid moments with the teams.
    - Recollect specific insights after back-to-back meetings.
    - Summarise team notes across standard set of dimensions.

    I'm playing with a workflow idea for https://chattermatter.xyz

    1. Select your use case.
    2. Upload your file.
    3. While uploading and processing, enter your notes from the call.
    4. Once done, get a report that covers different dimensions of the call for your use case – all while taking your notes into account. You also get the transcript, for a deeper dive if you need one.

    This is what I've done recently and it's a great documentation starter. Especially when incorporating your notes – ChatGPT then understands what highlights are important to you so it doesn't miss them out. (usually)

    What do you do with your call transcripts?

    Success is not one-size-fits-all.

    And this game has never been about emulating some "paint-by-numbers" journey.

    John CutlerJohn Cutler • FollowingVerified • Following Head of Product @Dotwork ex-{Company Name}Head of Product @Dotwork ex-{Company Name} 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Are you an "over-thinker"? Is your superpower (and achilles heel) being able to "go deep" on complex, thorny challenges and connect the dots? Well...

    ▶ Take care of yourself. Your brain is working overtime—all the time. Practice “radical” recovery.

    ▶ You may spend a lot longer thinking about things than most people. Pace your delivery.

    ▶ If you go deep first, and then simplify…keep in mind that you don’t need to show all of your work.

    ▶ Your default description of (almost) any problem will be too threatening/overwhelming.

    ▶ Do your deepest thinking with co-conspirators (not the people you’re trying to influence).

    ▶ Informal influence is often not formally recognized. Prepare mentally for this.

    ▶ The people you’re trying to influence spend 98% of their day overwhelmed by business as usual.

    ▶ Remember to also do the job you were hired to do (if you don’t you’ll be easier to discount).

    ▶ Seek “quick wins”, but know that most meaningful things will take a while.

    ▶ Some things take ages to materialize. It is discontinuous, not continuous.

    ▶ Make sure to celebrate your wins. They will be few and far between, so savor the moment.

    ▶ The people who support you in private may not be able to support you in public. Accept that.

    ▶ Hack existing power structures—it’s much easier than trying to change them.

    ▶ Consider becoming a formal leader. It’s harder in many ways, but you’ll have more leverage. What’s stopping you?

    ▶ In lieu of being a formal leader, make sure to partner with people who actually “own” the area of change.

    ▶ Watch out for imposing your worldview on people. Have you asked about what people care about?.

    ▶ You’ll need a support network. And not just a venting network. Real support.

    ▶ “Know when to fold ‘em”. Listen to Kenny Rogers The Gambler. Leave on your own terms.

    ▶ Don’t confuse being able to sense/see system dynamics, with being about to “control” them. You can’t.

    ▶ Grapple with your demons, and make sure not to wrap up too much of your identity in change.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • Edited • 2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    This goes well with this skewed idea that you should use ChatGPT to *source post ideas* which you then fill in.

    That makes no sense. Not for your own creativity, not for your personal brand and not for the world. It should be the reverse.

    I use ChatGPT all the time. Every day. I never ask for topic ideas and I've stopped "touching up" my writing with ChatGPT. It removes the little details that make things authentically mine. I used to try and remind it "English is not my native language, please don't make it sound like it is". But guess what works even better? 🥁 Just actually writing it myself. Who'd tell! 🤯

    If you lack ideas, practice it. This keeps your brain in shape, which is apparently also one of the predictors of longetivity. Then use ChatGPT to get different angles, improve the structure or such. It fills in to your ideas and thoughts and not the other way around.
    Arijan MuratovicArijan Muratovic • 2ndVerified • 2nd Manager Corporate Communication @ Flix | Thought Leadership | Future Of MobilityManager Corporate Communication @ Flix | Thought Leadership | Future Of Mobility 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Please stop using copy-pasting from ChatGPT and pretending it's your own thoughts. It's boring, it sucks, and you lose your authenticity.
    There is a high probability that you are posting here to either build your personal brand, position yourself as an expert in your field, or even a thought leader.
    🚫 Copy-pasting from ChatGPT does nothing good for that.
    You. Are. Sounding. Just. Like. Everyone. Else. Here.
    💤 And it's lazy and boring. Everyone can see right through it, and it does nothing to establish you as someone people would want to interact with.
    🙃 What is the point of engaging with a post so clearly written by a machine learning algorithm? Sure, you might have given it a prompt, but the text and thoughts are so clearly not yours.
    👉 And honestly, it makes people feel less of you. It's not authentic, it's not that interesting, and the reason people go on LinkedIn is to engage with intelligent, authentic, and interesting people.

    You won't be seen as a thought leader by copy-pasting from the algorithm. We want YOUR ideas.
    I am not saying, don't use ChatGPT. I am saying - don’t copy-paste from it. I am willing to bet that you are a much more interesting (aka better) writer than this generic style that everyone uses now.
    💡 Here are 3 ways you can still use ChatGPT to help you write your post without copy-pasting it:
    1. Ask it for content ideas based on your topics.
    2. Use it to structure your points. Sure, give it a prompt, but cherry-pick which parts of the text you like and write them in your own words.
    3. Use it to proofread your text and give inputs on how to make it more concise.

    In general, write like you speak. There's no reason to use fancy words. People want authenticity, give it to them, and you will be seeing far better results here too.

  • Feed post number 125

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    I got 10×-40× cheaper audio transcriptions for long audio interviews by hacking together a bash script with OpenAI.

    𝐅𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭, 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐥𝐞𝐦:
    We visited a number of customers and recorded the sessions with audio. Ended up with >600min of audio. We took some notes, but those did not capture all the details. Our schedule was packed and processing interviews on the same day wasn't realistic.

    𝐒𝐨𝐥𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐦𝐩𝐭 𝟏:
    Use OpenAI Whisper to transcribe. However, there's a limit of 26MB/request. Compressing files only lead to poor audio and translations like "Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah." 🎤

    𝐒𝐨𝐥𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐦𝐩𝐭 𝟐:
    There's *plenty* of tools out there, but they would cost us $150 easily for this. Some have free tiers for just 3 files or up to X minutes etc. And most were overblown Featuresteins of products that I didn't want to deal with. I saw a better way.

    𝐅𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐥 𝐬𝐨𝐥𝐮𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:
    I had ChatGPT help me write a bash script that uses 𝚏𝚏𝚖𝚙𝚎𝚐 to split the audio into chunks of 10 minutes, then transcribe each one with Whisper and combine it all into a .txt file. This took longer than I hoped but in the end it works beautifully. Since Whisper is $0.006/minute, this will cost around $0.40-$0.70 per interview in the future.
    Then I copy the final transcript – around 70kb of text – straight into ChatGPT and chat about it. The large context window is ❤️‍🔥.

    𝐍𝐨𝐭𝐞𝐬:
    - I prematurely tried to incorporate summarisation into the script too. What I learned is that you can't really reduce the entire interview summary into one prompt. It's more of a chat-loop where you add your notes, ask follow up questions, ask for more quotes etc.

    - Occasionally there's an issue where ChatGPT mistakes our statements with customers' statements. Detecting speakers with diarization would probably solve this, but since the interviews were still fresh in my memory, I could notice this and nudge ChatGPT in the right direction.

    - This was fun but there's probably an open source tool out there that can do this already at the bare-metal price, I just didn't bother enough to find it. Google Cloud Speech-to-Text has a more complex workflow but could remove the need to split the audio. I valued simplicity in this case.

    - You really have to know the interview to chat with it effectively. Otherwise ChatGPT will minimise points it should not or entirely skip things that matter. It works best if you take good notes and bring those to chat.

    Darko Stanimirović reposted this
    Derek YangDerek Yang • FollowingVerified • Following Principal Product Manager @ Roblox | derekyang.substack.comPrincipal Product Manager @ Roblox | derekyang.substack.com 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    3 takeaways from the latest season of Succession.

    1️⃣ Rapid, graceful recovery is always possible.

    We've seen a lot of layoffs this year. Anyone impacted has (rightfully) needed time to process and gather themselves before jumping into next steps.

    What Sam Altman just experienced was perhaps 100X more shocking (surprise coup to forcefully remove him as CEO of the most successful AI start up that he founded). But he sprung into action in mere hours.

    A day later, he was in talks to raise funds for a new venture. Two days later, he had a new leadership opportunity at Microsoft.

    I'm certain he felt betrayed. The shock, anger, and anxiety must have been nearly impossible to stave off. Yet, he persisted and made his best available moves, when he had every right to sulk for a few days.

    2️⃣ Trust is everything.

    It's clear to me that Greg has incredible amounts of organizational and personal trust.

    When news about Sam broke, everyone was in a holding pattern. Rumors were flying about what Sam could have done to justify removal (Safety, AGI, conflict of interest). When Greg announced his departure, the conversation changed.

    The board came under fire. Employees declared they would leave if the change was not reverted. That's the type of reputation that can only be earned through years of integrity and leadership.

    Greg's resignation was the catalyst that got 95% of OpenAI staff vocally behind them. That speaks volumes to the kind of leaders he and Sam are, and how much the OpenAI team trusts them.

    Sam and Greg can ONLY have uno-reversed this board coup with this much trust.

    3️⃣ Microsoft "can't lose".

    In spite of Satya's mild demeanor and PC tone, Microsoft really held all the cards. It has ~49% ownership of OpenAI, it has licensing to OpenAI's tech assets (e.g. models), and provides a significant amount of compute credit that OpenAI needs in order to operate.

    If Sam and Greg go to Microsoft, they can hit the ground running. They would likely bring a significant swing of talent to Microsoft (more than just OpenAI talent). OpenAI's value would sharply decline, and the board would have no company to oversee.

    If Sam and Greg go back to OpenAI, they can continue their mission toward AGI as a separate entity. They would ensure governance changes so nothing like this happens again. With that firm grasp on the company, they won't forget that Satya and Microsoft had their backs during this time.

    If you enjoyed this, follow me Derek Yang for more.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Mildly hot take: The product brief should be a pain in the ass for the product manager, not a safe zone.

    And it comes down to problem understanding.

    In the Problem Section of the brief, I use a JTBD statement but take it a step further with a critical aspect of JTBD: a list of user's progress metrics.

    𝑷𝒓𝒐𝒃𝒍𝒆𝒎 𝒔𝒕𝒂𝒕𝒆𝒎𝒆𝒏𝒕:
    When I [situational context]
    I [do action]
    So that [expected outcome].
    The way I evaluate progress is:
     - [progress metric 1]
     - [progress metric 2]
     - [progress metric 3]

    In the JTBD theory – but also in the theory of common sense – when people get their jobs done, they have a set of metrics to evaluate the progress. These metrics are solution-agnostic.

    Strategyn uses a method of extracting these *desired outcome* statements and claims there's often more than 100 per job.

    A product manager (or for that matter, researcher) who has intimate understanding of the problem should be able to extract a few.

    Without the metrics in place, solutions can go in many different ways. Best case scenario, you tick a metric or two. Most likely, you copy what others are doing, and with it you inherit their problems. Best case, you bring innovation in a saturated space because you've gained an intimate, nuanced understanding of the problem.

    This is hard though. But again, hashtag#product briefs should be hard. We just sometimes like to make it a simple fill-in-the-blanks form to pass the feature over.

    What does your brief template start with?

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Engineers regularly diminish the chances of being hired by focusing exclusively on technical skills.

    Everyone has those 15 frameworks covered.
    Everyone’s worked with hashtag#MongoDB and hashtag#Postgres.
    Everyone built the UI or the hashtag#backend for whatever new feature.

    While you certainly need to tick the right technology boxes for the role, you can stand out by complementing technical skills with end-user care.

    Your end users may be customers or internal users. You're always building for someone. (Hopefully 😅)

    - You didn’t just help build a component library. You helped provide a more consistent experience for the customers. This also made sales and marketing interactive demos look great and drive the initial Wow moment.

    - You didn't just Dockerize a few services. You reduced the onboarding time for new hires at the time of team expansion, impacting new team velocity and satisfaction.

    – You didn't just optimise the pod configuration for queues to keep them from failing. You decreased the time for customers to get their reports, improving the key conversion event in the product.

    You can't just make this stuff up though. Don't use AI. Try to genuinely get the information. It's there, you know.

    Engineers are famously not seeing the bigger picture of their work. It's sad and they're not the only to blame.

    If you're one of those who's not sure what, if any, impact your work has had, you can try this:

    1. Follow up on the projects you work on with whoever is the lead. Specifically ask for customer impact. If they don't know, dig deeper. In fact, don't wait on them. Learn how to get the data.

    2. If you're not sure how a ticket/project/epic/brief addresses a customer need, bring it up. You need to know the purpose behind the ticket. (Then later use it in your CV)

    3. Speak with your lead and ask to be included on customer calls. Sounds crazy? Because it's only crazy this is not happening more often.

    4. Don't underestimate your work.

    This is how you stand out. In your current role, and when applying. Engineers like these are rare, and everyone wants them. And yes, you still need to be pretty good at writing code.

    - Adjectives will be limited to 5, of which "delectable" is not a part of.

    - It will not be awfully grandiose.
    - Its writing structure will be chaotic at times.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    There's something weirdly satisfying about revamping complex legacy systems.

    Odds are stacked against you:

    - Power users "LOVE IT."
    - The code is chaotic, and so much as altering a button's colour becomes a multi-week project that nobody wants to tackle.
    - The organisation is attuned to maintaining the status quo.
    - The full scope of UI states and use cases remains a mystery to everyone.

    It demands an extraordinary effort, yet it can yield profound satisfaction and significantly boost your expertise and capabilities.

    Here's what I've learned so far:

    - You learn that fostering relationships with other stakeholders is invaluable.

    - The complexity conceals a wealth of past decisions. It's less of a rabbit hole and more of a treasure trove. Dig into it, and you'll uncover a multitude of valuable insights. Sort of like a time machine.

    - You'll navigate through various layers of abstraction all the time. Mastering the art of being effective—and efficient—in this is a great skill.

    - You'll learn to go beyond the "power users love it" to both improve their workflows and revamp the product for new users. You don't get this with simple apps that are just getting out to the market.

    - You'll come to understand that complex systems aren't inherently bad. Context is key, and you'll learn to appreciate the subtleties. This skill, once carried into a new role, will stand out.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    ChatGPT wrappers are starting to feel the pain of not having a vertical advantage.

    Incumbents are hard to disrupt since they already own the workflows, have a great UX, have money to burn, and embedding GenAI into those workflows is seamless.

    As Sangeet Paul Choudary points out in his 2-part series on Losing and Winning with GenAI (links in comments), wrappers are poorly positioned to win:

    - No pre-existing PMF to subsidise the cost of GenAI,
    - No other vertical advantage,
    - Mediocre workflow UX.

    The recent expansion of ChatGPT into native PDF support is a good example.

    - "Chatting with PDF" is a great use case for embeddings. But it is so close to the capability of a foundational model that you'd have to provide additional value *fast* if you want to protect yourself.

    - Wrappers are trying to take a horizontal model (good at everything but not truly great at anything) and take it to a vertical. However, PDF embeddings aren't exactly a vertical, which made it extremely easy, even necessary for the foundational model provider to own it. The fact that PDF wrappers didn't see it coming isn't surprising given the GenAI gold rush.

    - Perhaps traditionally, plugin marketplaces don't go competing with their plugins very often. I think this is because the path to a platform is a long one, and the company has usually figured out main use cases by then. For OpenAI, or specifically ChatGPT, this path was extremely short. For comparison, it took Figma 6 years to move into a platform, and it took ChatGPT *5 months*.

    - Whether it was intentionally built as a data mining strategy to see emerging use cases and then bundle them in, or not, is hard to say. Looking back, building your core value proposition on top of a steaming hot tech, embedding it within the model provider's platform and creating no other vertical advantage was perhaps not meant to succeed.

    * LinkedIn releases AI assistant for job applications * (link in comments)
    Another great use case. Job searching is extremely painful and slow. Simple AI wrappers won't cut it because AI applications are easy to see through. You need a strong vertical advantage and a great UX to win. Incumbents like LinkedIn are deeply positioned to win here. Even beyond matching "CV" and job ad, LinkedIn can match an applicant's posts history to bring the nuance into the process. (E.g. "this applicant frequently writes about onboarding and UX, both of which are stated as important in your job ad.")

    For wrappers to create this vertical advantage, Sangeet Paul Choudary offers a playbook:

    1. Sophisticated prompt engineering + Well-crafted UX drives Workflow engagement.
    2. Workflow engagement drives rich data capture.
    3. Data capture aids model fine-tuning.
    4. A fine-tuned model drives greater workflow engagement.

    Building a hashtag#genai wrapper but lacking on hashtag#uxdesign? Want to explore how hashtag#genai can boost your PLG onboarding? Reach out.

    The real trouble is when a startup acts like they are at scale but they are not really past the PMF. This can send mixed signals to designers who then fall for:

    - "There's a ton of pages in the app already, let's unify all of this"
    - "If a UI element appears at two places, it MUST be a design component detailed in Figma and Storybook"
    - "They have a component library so they must still need it and want to scale it even further"
    - "The engineering/design/whoever lead says they need to really ramp up their component library"
    - "Nice, even the co-founder says he'd like me to lead the design system effort, he loves design systems!"

    Killing the design system efforts can be a painful idea. Some people just love a thought of having a nice thing to show.

    So it's not just about a designer joining a company and having their perspective skewed. It's a lot harder when there's already a lot of investment in the idea made internally, and you need to critically evaluate it and possibly suggest shooting it down. Because hey, how could a designer actually be against having a design system??

    Instead, they care about 👇

    → Translating their ideas into tangible user flows
    → An interface that is both visually stunning and usable
    → Having an interactive prototype to play with

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Documentation is how LLMs learn in the first place. What's changing now isn't that documentation itself is becoming obsolete. It's only going to be used by LLMs as well as people.

    All in all, it should be a net gain, not loss:

    – LLMs can generate documentation for us, or assist in the process. The dreaded writing process will become more of an instruction-review-feedback loop with an LLM. This can be great if it results in more/better documentation written overall.

    – The final documentation will live on, but how we measure success (page visits, "X people found this helpful") will need to adapt. Perhaps there will be ways to test the quality differently – either checklists (like "has version-specific documentation") or some version of accessibility tests which would help LLMs understand information more accurately (e.g. comparison tables use either text values or images/SVG with aria values, and not plan images) or a more advanced test, like making sure information is structured well enough for embeddings to be effective.

    – The layer between the documentation and someone's specific problem will largely get replaced by an LLM. Not great for StackOverflow but pretty cool for engineers. So it's more about the middleman than the documentation itself.

    As an example, I PoC'd a Zapier app recently for the first time, never before reading Zapier's docs and never using our own product's GraphQL API or even writing a line of GraphQL before.

    That internal GraphQL API documentation was the absolute enabler for the fast PoC. I still had to consult both documentations and of course use my own logic, but the approach made me at least 3x efficient, due to my non-existent previous experience with either ends of the integration.

    I say the documentation is here to stay, but many things will change. How we write it, how we access it, how we measure it.
    Travis OliphantTravis Oliphant • 2ndPremium • 2nd Connecting Companies with Communities | CEO/Founder of Quansight | Head of Open Source at Zyphra | Principal OSA/Founder at OpenTeams | Founder of Anaconda, NumFOCUS, and PyData | Creator of NumPy, SciPy, and NumbaConnecting Companies with Communities | CEO/Founder of Quansight | Head of Open Source at Zyphra | Principal OSA/Founder at OpenTeams | Founder of Anaconda, NumFOCUS, and PyData | Creator of NumPy, SciPy, and Numba 2yr • Edited • 2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    The temptation to copy and paste code snippets from ChatGPT or Stackoverflow is real, but true mastery lies in comprehension.

    Like everyone else, I have also used "cut-and-paste" to get started from another appropriately licensed open-source codebase. But as a programmer, cut-and-paste is just the beginning. It is your duty and opportunity to understand.

    And to do so, you'll eventually end up in documentation 😉.

    For some reason, this is amusing.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    This is what we are seeing more and more of. People using AI to brainstorm content ideas that they then fill in with their own perspectives.

    I've nothing against using AI to boost content production in relevant areas or business. However, I do have a problem with the idea that we need to fill into content that AI deems post-worthy.

    It should be the other way around.

    Write from your own experience. Write your own thoughts down. Then use AI to improve the writing, bring a better perspective, get a critical analysis and more.

    AI fills in to your perspective.

    Not you filling in to the AI perspective.

    Not that that is absolutely wrong in every context – like AI for SEO where you tweak the AI-generated content – but if you use it to build a personal brand, I'd avoid it.
    Sam SzuchanSam Szuchan • 2ndPremium • 2nd Founder, Soleo. Creating influence.Founder, Soleo. Creating influence. 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Using ChatGPT for LinkedIn Content? It's not just about speed.

    The sooner you figure this out?

    The better, more impactful, and more authentic posts you'll create.

    Because here's the deal:

    AI isn't going to write your memoirs for you.

    Your unique expertise and stories? Those are yours to tell.

    But let's not kid ourselves—efficiency is key, especially in the creator economy.

    So, don't be this person:

    "Let's churn out 10 posts today using an AI generator, who cares about relevance or depth..."

    Instead, be this person:

    "I'm going to leverage ChatGPT to brainstorm and draft ideas, then add my personal expertise and stories to make it authentic."

    Take the time to integrate AI and human touch.

    By blending AI's efficiency with your unique insight?

    You'll master the LinkedIn game.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Being too data-driven isn’t to blame. Your poor data culture is.

    Here are the symptoms you attribute to “being too data-driven”:

    ＊ 𝗢𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲, 𝘂𝘀𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝘀𝗵𝗮𝗹𝗹𝗼𝘄 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗽𝗼𝗶𝗻𝘁𝘀 ＊
    People associate that kind of impulsive, reactive state of mind as being “driven by data”. You can’t be data-driven if you have poor data or stop at the surface level.

    Data is like an onion. You have to peel a few layers to get to the meat. Segmenting by customer groups, seeing historic trends, understanding seasonality etc. are some examples of how to get there.

    ＊ 𝗣𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗹𝗮𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗯𝗲𝗰𝗮𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 “𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗲𝗻𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮” ＊
    You could argue this is a data-driven mindset since these people will not move until they can back a decision with hard data.

    The problem is elsewhere though: people are not equipped with enough domain experience, they don’t feel empowered to act on “just enough data”, or you have a gap in your onboarding process, or more. All signs of a poor data culture, not a problem with being data-driven per se.

    ＊ 𝗚𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗮 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗹𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘆 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝗼𝗻 𝘀𝗲𝗻𝘀𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿𝘀 ＊
    Team members go deep into data but you’re like “well duh, we know that”.

    Yet it turns out, this knowledge isn’t documented anywhere. You know it, or the team member with the longest tenure knows it, but no one else does.

    Again, the problem isn’t being data-driven. Your poor data culture makes business critical insights a personal knowledge trophy of hard to reach individuals.

    ＊ 𝗪𝗲 𝗸𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝗴𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗹𝘆𝘀𝗶𝘀-𝗽𝗮𝗿𝗮𝗹𝘆𝘀𝗶𝘀 ＊
    This is not an uncommon problem, but usually it’s a symptom of:

    – Toxic blame culture that discourages people from making decisions with just enough data.
    – Unclear goals which make people dig into data without a clear outcome in mind.
    – Lack of a decision-making process.

    Most of the time you’re looking at a non-intentional, poor data culture.

    Like any culture, it already exists and you probably don’t create it consciously. Yet everything you do around data is shaping it.

    If it’s not intentional, it can take all kinds of shapes and forms as you scale – as evident in the realistic representation of a poor data culture in the attachment.

    Next time, if you see the blame passed to "data-driven", probe the culture a bit. I guarantee the outcomes will be more actionable and impactful.

    Darko StanimirovićDarko Stanimirović • YouYou Senior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AISenior Product Manager ⌁ Building with AI 2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    Do you still start with "Welcome to [Product Name]" in your onboarding? You might reconsider.

    These phrases can feel like filler text, almost saying, "I wasn't really sure what to put here."

    It's weak because users typically have several questions in mind when they begin.

    Hitting them with "Welcome to [MY_PRODUCT]" or "Hello, [FIRST_NAME]"? That's a direct path to banner blindness.

    Being welcomed is more about feeling than being told. You can say it, but it doesn’t guarantee the user will FEEL it.

    Instead, they might feel:

    – Lost. "Where am I? Is this right?"
    – Confused. "What's in it for me?"
    – Annoyed. "This isn't what I was looking for."

    True welcoming comes from job alignment and clear progress.

    * Alignment *

    The product must resonate with the user's specific needs and the job they intend to complete. Alignment gap almost always exists, but can be thoughtfully minimised.
    A disjointed onboarding experience widens this gap. Poorly designed products often completely miss the user's expectations.

    * Progress to the desired outcome *

    In the Jobs to Be Done (JTBD) theory, users “hire” products to achieve progress towards their desired outcome. If they can't see how hiring your product progresses them further, the big “Welcome, Bob!” won’t do much.

    It's like mistakenly crashing a party. They might drunkenly exclaim “Welcome to the partey!” but you know you need to get out asap.

    A clear progression path could be as basic as a descriptive headline or a CTA that says “Customize Report” over a vague “Next”.

    So, next time you're tempted to slap a "Welcome" on the screen, pause.

    List out 3 things that would make users FEEL it, so they know they’re at the right party.

    Then craft the message around one of these.

    (And if you hit a snag, ping me.)

    To become a top-notch web designer, the #1 rule is mastery in drawing and painting.

    That's what I wrote in 2002. I was a "pro" web designer, boasting maybe an entire year of experience, mainly building websites for buddies in Macromedia Dreamweaver and Flash. 🤷‍♂️

    I stumbled upon these .doc files in my archive, one of them titled simply: "What it takes". 👊

    Here are the main points, with all their authentic typos and grammar:

    – “The first thing that you must have is fondness against visual arts.” 😬

    – “Not only web design, but drawing, painting, photography, modeling, and well, every other form of visual arts.” Cool story bro 🤣

    – “If you dislike, for instance, photography as an art… then I think you should give up”. 📸 Definitely give up. This is a rock solid advice here.

    I couldn't resist but challenge ChatGPT to give my younger self's wisdom a modern twist and see if the message can find a new following.

    So here's to my younger self. I salute you. 🫡

    ---

    Sipping coffee one afternoon, I found myself deep in conversation with a friend about the essence of web design.

    He hit me with a question: "What truly sets a web designer apart?" I pondered, and the answer struck me like a flash of inspiration. "The first thing that you must have is fondness against visual arts,” I remarked.

    But what does 'fondness for visual arts' really mean? I went on, “Not only web design, but drawing, painting, photography, modeling (not referring to 3D modeling for games ;), and well, all other forms of visual arts.” I caught a look of confusion from him, clearly thinking, "I’ve no idea what this guy is talking about.”

    But the deeper I delved into the topic, the clearer it became. 🤯

    As the hours passed, I touched upon the significance of every art form. "If you dislike, say, photography as an art... then I think you should give up,” I declared. And while it might sound harsh, it's rock-solid advice, people.

    Because true web design isn't just about laying out a page; it's about pouring heart, soul, and art into every pixel.

    As our conversation dwindled and the coffee cups emptied, I felt a renewed sense of purpose. For me, and many like me, the canvas of the web is where art meets function, where passion meets precision. Every site, every page, tells a story - and behind it is a designer letting their love for the visual arts shine through. 🎨💞✨

    2yr • 2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
    I bootstrapped 3 startups in 13 years. These are the 8 biggest misconceptions I always hear about bootstrappers: 🧐

    1. We raise $0 external capital.
    Unless founders can avoid hiring, cover startup costs, and sustain themselves till they get to revenue, it’s likely that they’ll need some initial capital. Bootstrapping refers to "no institutional capital". Most founders invest their own money and raise from family and friends to get started.

    2. We don't want to give away equity.
    It took 2.5 hard years in my last startup to make our first $10. A friend said to me, "It’s okay to raise a bit so you can be comfortable.” thinking I didn’t raise because I wanted to keep all the equity. Reality was, I had complete freedom and didn't want to lose it.

    3. We're less ambitious.
    "If you don't shoot for unicorn status, you're not ambitious enough." is a fallacy fueled by VCs because it's good for their business. Starting a company is in itself ambition. We know success is self-defined, we don't need anyone else to agree.

    4. We're unable to raise capital.
    VC-backed startups must fuel growth at all costs, which forces them into a vicious cycle of constantly raising more. We don't subscribe to that way of life. At least not yet until we know that's what we want. Many bootstrappers raise much later when they can demand favorable terms.

    5. We're cheap.
    We're cost conscious and optimize for getting the most return on investment. That's not the same as cheap, which means paying the least. We're profit driven, so we can't afford to compromise on time and quality of work. We pay what is needed to get to revenue fastest.

    6. We don't make money for a while.
    We make money, just not yet on the startup we're bootstrapping. We do whatever it takes to fund our companies. We work on them on the side, take consulting gigs, or agency work.

    7. We have smaller exits.
    We can sell whenever we want but VC-backed startups can't without board approval and often come with liquidation preferences. Selling a bootstrapped startup at $10m where founders own 90% = $9m. To do better, VC-backed founders need 10% of a $100m exit which is often not big enough for VCs.

    8. We struggle more.
    It's true that comparatively we struggle more in the initial years. But our struggle ends the day we hit profitability. We don't need to grow at an unrealistic pace to satisfy investors until we sell or die. Profitability gives us the freedom to live and work how we want. 🍾

    Many people think bootstrapping is a financial decision when it's often a lifestyle choice.

    Raising VC, however, is usually a financial decision without consideration for the lifestyle that comes with it.

    There isn’t a right or wrong way to build a business. But there's a right way FOR YOU.

    The question founders should be asking before choosing which path to take is not, "How much money do I want to make from this?"

    But rather, "What kind of life do I want to live while building this for the next 10 years?"

    Jason FriedJason Fried • 2ndInfluencer • 2nd Started and runs 37signalsStarted and runs 37signals

    CALM IS IN THE BLACK

    From the very first month we started the business back in 1999, we were profitable. We’ve remained profitable every year since then.

    We’ve absolutely had our share of good fortune and luck, but we’ve also intentionally never gotten ahead of ourselves. We’ve always kept our costs in check and never made a move that would push us back from black to red.

    Why? Because crazy’s in the red. Calm’s in the black.

    Until you’re running a profitable business, you’re always almost out of business. You’re racing the runway. Fretting about whether you’ll take off in time. Worrying about how to make payroll at the last moment if you don’t. Talk about a pressurized environment!

    When companies are in the red, employees worry about their jobs. People aren’t stupid—they know that burning cash means the good times won’t last. The possibility of layoffs are always nagging. CVs are always at the ready. And as market sentiments change, valuations shift, and money becomes more expensive, being in the red leads to even more danger ahead.

    Revenue alone is no defense either because revenue without a profit margin isn’t going to save you. You can easily go broke generating revenue—many companies have. But you can’t go broke generating a profit.

    Profit means time to think, space to explore. It means being in control of your own destiny and schedule.

    Without profit, something is always on fire. When companies talk about burn rates, two things are burning: money and people. One you’re burning up, one you’re burning out.

    The response I've seen (and had myself) to hashtag#generative hashtag#AI pretty much demonstrates Clayton Christensen's theory of Disruptive Innovation. Here's what that looks like in the hashtag#design space. Same goes for everyone else, just put your own response to AI and see where it fits. As AI moves up the market and our response to it is more high level, we accept that we've integrated – in some cases plain lost – the market below it.

    Now, "lost" may or may not be a strong word. We only see short-term. Don't extrapolate too far out based on the immediate (and limited) impact.
